500ml bottle, labeled Rauch Geek Breakfast, from the greenville beer exchange. pours a silky, pure black with a thick, creamy, dark beige head that has outstanding retention and leaves thick sheets of lace. aroma is wonderful with huge notes of peat, campfire smoke, freshly melted tar, and cigar ash backed by subtle notes of roast coffee, dark chocolate, and salty molasses. flavor is delcious as well with the base beer notes of dark chocolate, fresh roasted coffee, and raw oats coming through and balancing the savory notes of smoked meat, charred wood, salty pretzel with hints of earthy hops and molasses on the back end. palate is medium bodied with brisk carbonation and a long, lingering, smokey and bittersweet cocoa finish. overall, a great smoked brew.

Hot damn this was quite the beer.  Started out opaque black with a brown head.  Aroma was of smoked pork and heavy smoke.  Hints on roasty chocolate malt.  It was like smelling a wood burning stove.  Taste was smoky almost like charcoal and bitter dark chocolate.  Finish was bitter but not from hops and like roasted coffee and mocha.  Mildly sweet.  This was a bit astringent but not off putting.  Palate was creamy and almost gritty at the end.  One of the best in a while. (Mikkeller Rauch Geek Breakfast)

Bottle 50 cl tasted @ Karhisma Birroteca (Piedimonte Matese, Caserta - Italy). Flavorsome aroma of bacon, molasses, smoked cheese, woody, roasted sugar, chocolate, coffee. Intense dark head, not so wide anyway. Creamy-oily full body, really good feeling about its dainty like velvet that warms palate. Among above-mentioned roasted and smoked malty notes, theres a nice oatmeal, coffee and chocolate again. Crisp, doubtless crisp, balanced carbonation. Some ashes. Roasty and bitter lasting finish. Below the Alaskan Smoked Porter IMO, but one of the best smoked ever had still.

Boy, I feel like Ive hit the jackpot tonight.  Double Simcoe unfiltered followed by this gem.  Dark brown pour with a tan head and nice lacing.  Smoke aroma with undertones of molasses, caramel, rich chocolate, and coffee.  Not for the faint of heart.  This packs a flavor punch, and it certainly hits the spot.  Really nice offering, once again from Mikkeller.

Shared 0.5l bottle. Pours a near black body with near no head. Really nice aroma: mildly smoked and roasted, light woody and some thin chocolate next to a little coffee. Really full-bodied has a fantastic creamy mouthfeeling and low on the carbonation. The flavors really brings back some good memories from the time I sat @ Mikkeller Bar with a bottle of this fantastic brew and got totally blown away from the fantastic "thick flavors". Nice fatty bacon with dark bitter chocolate - combined with milk chocolate, coffee, a little burned toast and slightly ashy. Ends warming with a long lasting roasted aftertaste. Beautiful!

Bottle (Rauch Geek Breakfast label).  Pours black with a thick luxurious chocolate colored head.  Aroma of smoke, lots of smoke, with some roasted malt (although not particularly meaty nor bacony).  Flavor with more of a rich smoky meat feel, plenty of regular smoky qualities, and charred roasted malt.  An ok smoked, but kinda expected more from Mikkeller...
7/4/7/4/14 [3.6/5]

Single bottle purchased from Kensington Wine Market in Calgary, AB in April, 2011. Colour: Black and black and more black. Dark low head. Nose: Hickory smoke, actual pork, railroad tar, spoiled egg. Best of both worlds... Taste: Medium-light sweet, medium bitter, medium-light sour. More hickory smoke, salty, caramalized onion, almost gritty finish that rings sweet & sour. Not as good as I was expecting, rather a disapointment. Again an applause for creativity that does not a great beer make.

I just had a sample of this at TJs in Phoenixville, but Im rating it anyway. The aroma is INTENSE!! Like a stout but multiplied by a million. Very smokey. However, compared to other smoked beers Ive had, this one has a pleasant smoked flavor thats not overwhelming.
Mycket rökig doft. Även smaken har mycket rök och sälta, annars är ölen faktisk rätt tunn jämfört med breakfast och brunch. Liten besvikelse.

Bottle. Pours a beautiful black with sexy tan lacing. Aroma of shoe leather, chocolate, and smoky goodness. Flavor is full of black chocolate with notes of chalk and tar. A soft smoky quality in the background. Dark chocolate and coffee both strong in the finish, along with the smoke. Not obnoxious, but the smoke is plenty prominent. Very well done.

Appearance: very dark opaque brown with a rich, frothy, creamy two-finger head the color and consistency of chocolate milk; ton of lacing.   Aroma: 	smoke, wood, hint of toasted oats, and smoke; theres also a slightly weird note of new shower curtain.   Taste: big hit of smoky wood, with definite notes of meat (more like steak or pulled pork than bacon); as it warms, more of the oaty stout comes out, then a hint of the acidic coffee and piney hops.   Finish: long, smooth, chalky, lightly bitter, but mainly the smoke is what lingers	.   Notes: Very enjoyable.  Beautiful beer to look at, and the palate was phenomenal.  The smoke was a little on the overpowering side, rather than the complementary.  Would have liked it dialed down a titch, with a little more emphasis given back to the rich oats, bittersweet chocolate and coffee that you get in the normal version.  Still very, very good.

(50 cl bottle from Toft Vin) Pours black with impressive, long-lasting toffee-coloured head that laces the glass in heavy curtains for every sip. Aroma of peat, smoke and rain coat. Mostly burnt and bitter taste of licorice, coffee and hobs. Hits the palate with a softly carbonated, creamy texture full-bodied with a long, astringent finish. The smokiness of this beer is very different from the Schlenkerla that Ive tried. It resembes more something coming from a whisky barrel.

I dont get it? what am I missing? Why do people like this beer? Am I crazy or do people just pretend to like it because its called bacon? Thick blackish brown with a massive brown cap, insane lacing left behind with every sip. Aroma is an oily burnt bacon, with massive camping smoke, and reminds me of boiling pot of roofing tar. Did I just smell old fashion  1980s arousal bug spray? Ugg, ACK, splaaaa!!! What did I just put in my mouth? So very oily tasting and feeling. I can taste burnt charcoal bacon that has absorbed all the fat in the frying pan but then that fell into my cup of yummy coffee. So I really dig the thick coffee flavor here but his oily tar like camp fire smoke isnt doing it for me. Strange Im not sure what to think, the coffee base is good, I think I can even handle the smoke, but this pungent oil/tar mixed with ash is killing this beer for me. Im glad I split the bottle with my neibourhe now hates me. But im very glad i had a chance to try it.

holy fuck. thisll be my first post of a beer in quite possibly years. thanks to vertical bacon strips for this, and previous tastings of cellared and stellar, beers.

pouring into la fin du monde glass. first portion of the pour reveals an actual thick and meaty beer. likely im part to the ridiculous cap that follows. erp. theres a bit of chunky goodness that slops into the dense, tan cap. i take my time with this pour, to get almost all of the 50cl into the glass. even with a careful pour, the inverted nipple on a b-cup head (in proportion of glass opening of course) makes my dink-hole smile. im giggling like a school boy just looking at the beer.

i take a first taste just to make room for the last 2cl or so. beer is still a bit chilled, but i immediately taste the smoke. finishing off the pour, gives me a satisfaction as i see the crater in the middle of the cap.

i wait while the beer warms, and keep admiring the looks of the beer. a dense black body, with a deep tan cap that sticks. and sticks. and sticks. and keeps on sticking. thick cap just wont dissipate! once it eventually relaxes, it leaves a concavity that shows just how much it wants to stick to the glass.

the first smells at a cooler temp do reveal smoke and roasty goodness. gunna leave it for a bit.

more tastes once it gets to about 6 degrees im guessing, and i get a more intense smoke. not as much as i expected, but still better. i wait a couple more dozen minutes.

been a good chunk of airing now. with a quick smell, im immediately faced with blackened wood smell. but also reminds me of a meat chunk in my bbq that dropped into the flames 2 cookings ago, and is finally melting its buttery burnt smell into my nostrils and impregnating my present feast. after a swirl and more calm smell gives a similar creamery salted butter smell. definitely roasted coffee and slightly burnt chocolate smell up front. but also... raw prosciutto actually. very slight smokey saltiness. as i type this, i can smell the smoke sneaking its way to my face.

during this time, ive had more tastes. a light sweetness with mild bitterness. not as much as i expected. not sure what i was expecting, but the balance is nice. this compliments a creamy, full body mouthfeel. the mealiness of the beer now compliments the dense cap. but the mealiness isnt shunned. not a beer youre going to drink anything but slow, so its all gooood. no discernible aftertaste other than a slight smokiness that leaves the palate ready for another sip.

as i finish off this review, im taking a few last sips, and im pleased with this review. this is a great beer, and im thoroughly enjoying it. the "meat" of the beer and possible "mealiness" i got out of it was more apparent at optimal serving temps. following, left a well balanced and very palatable beer for a deep impy stout. think ill take me up on that! thanks to vertical bacon strips again!

A beer that is almost black and a huge head that is only a few shades lighter in color and that takes several minutes to collapse on the outside.  A tan mesa remains and cool lacing is left.  Big smoke on the nose with chocolate and, yes, bacon that is over cooked.  The flavor is dominated by smoke.  There is also some coffee and chocolate.  Soy sauce is also noted.  It has a thick feel and one that is fizzy.  This beer scores well largely because it looks so appetizing and feels so nice.  The flavor, while good, is not as tasty as the appearance would hint.

50cL bottle from Barleywine shop off Copenhagen Strøget. Pours black with a dark brown head. Smells smoky and of roasted malt with a touch of dark chocolate. Taste is smoky (smoked wood) with some roasted malt and, again, a touch of dark chocolate. Quite good, but not my favorite smoked beer.

Bottle 500ml @ Zoney
Pours pitch black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate and smoked malt. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Bodyy is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Churchkey, DC tap ($9): I thought that this was going to be an even more intense version of the already intense Breakfast; however, it seemed to me that this was even somewhat toned down. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma is smoky, but not to the extent of a rauchbier; smoked malts still do their work. A bit of coffee and chocolate is also present, as is typical. For me, this beer was a lot smoother than the normal Breakfast. Sure it was somewhat smoky, but the intense bitterness was lacking (and for me, that is probably a plus). I kind of wish it tasted like bacon, but it really didnt. In any case, this was not what I was expecting, but  was still a good beer.

Draft.  Brown head atop black body with brown edge.  Aroma is moderately sweet, smoke/ash, some milk chocolate, coffee/roast.  Taste is moderately sweet, ash/smoke, some chocolate, coffee grounds, bacony burp.  Medium body, low carbonation.

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of rich smoked meat (bacon), & burnt oak; Flavor of smoky/roasted malt, dark chocolate, espresso, caramel, and some hops; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, loved the smoked aroma - great brew.
Pitch dark brown, brown head. Aroma is extraordinary, heavy with coffee and smoke. Full oily palate. Coffee, dark chocolate, burned toast flavour. Really great.
Black with a nice brown head, but should hold a bit longer. Smell and taste is smoked malts, light spices, Bacon. Not totally my thing bit I think together with some bbq a good combination.
Deep black color.. Smells of bacon, sausage and smoke. Taste is thick like a stout, but not as heavy. Aftertaste lingers (draft)

16.9 oz. bottle. Pours black with a moderate brown head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left partial lace.  Very pleasant aroma of both wood and meat smoke, coffee, vanilla, and a few alcohol vapors.  The flavor is equally enjoyable with wood and meat smoke, roasted malt and coffee.  Ashy finish with some moderate coffee bitterness present as well.  I would have preferred a bit more body to support the complex and rich flavors of this beer, but that is a personal preference and not a criticism.  Went great with my buckwheat pancakes!
Challenging beer - not so much bacon as smokey and salty. Thick, rich flavours, not something your should drink on its own. Would pair well with cheese, wish Id had some when I tried this...

Bottle thanks to Savvy1982. Pours black with dark brown edges and a massive frothy brown head. Aroma has a nice malty and dark fruit sweetness and a great smokiness. Taste is sweet- mocha and milk chocolate, creamy, bitter chocolate finish. Taste is definitely smoked but does not taste burnt or charred. Its a very sweet smooth rich smoke. The body and texture is not as thick and chewy as I expected but that is in no way a bad thing. Medium high carbonation. Very good beer, sweet but there is enough bitter roast/coffee/smoke to balance it out nicely.

(bottle - 500 ml) Dark black with a creamy tan head. Big smoke aroma with lots of charcoal and chocolate notes. Some hints of smoked meat as well. Flavor is smoke and chocolate at the start with a nice roasted and smoky middle. Finishes with that same great smoke with a light hint of roasted malts and a light chocolate sweetness. Excellent.

Bottle from DeCicco Ardsley.  Black with thick tall brown head.  Smoky woody ashy earth and wet pine aroma.  Smoky roasted espresso woody rich but subdued dark fruit woody hop finish with lingering woody ash.  Rich complex and extremely delicious, but, even though Im a smokehead, Im not sure its better than the straightforward delicious rich and mellow Beer Geek Breakfast..  Nonetheless, fucking awesome.
Black color with no head.  Smokey aroma with coffee and roasted malt.  Flavor is much the same: smoke, roasted malt, coffee.  Some light lactose sugar sweetness on the end.
Catching up on old ratings. The one I had was a "Rauch Geek Breakfast". Definite bacon flavor, very good beer.

The pour is purely opaque black, viscous motor oil like pour. The head is a fluffy medium tan color that started at 2.5 fingers and died down to nearly nothing. The aroma is sweet and intense with a lingering campfire and smoke note throughout. The roasted malts are sweet and candy like in the aroma with notes of brown sugar, molasses, toffee and an ever overpowering smoke. The taste is sweet and malty in the middle with a hint of smoke roasted malts. The finish is huge smoke with a campfire  like taste stuck to the palate. Not really getting "bacon", but getting the smoke everywhere. This is a fantastic smoked beer and definately more like a Smoked porter than a rauchbier, but had the woody and earthy notes of rauchmalt. Overall, a great beer.

Pours dark black with prominent light brown head that lingers nicely with sticky lacing. The nose is so strong with smoke that I could smell 5 inches from the tulip glass. also a salty like odor (maybe that is why it is called Beer Geek Bacon). The first sip is strong with roasted and smoked flavors that change to coffee followed by smoke and bitter chocolate. Still has a clean finish. Very Good beer.

Bottle. Crazy dark pour. More thick chocolate frothy foam than beer in the glass. Twice the smoke scent as bacon and twice the bacon as beer so you can do the algebra on that one! Sharp, almost brings tears to the eyes; maybe Gramma left the bacon in the oven too long. Burnt bacon on aluminum foil flavour. Flavour does not live up to the imaganitive potential of the name or even the aroma.  Burnt aluminum bacon bits.
Bottle. Black beer with a huge quite dark brown head. Roasted smoky aroma, smoked fish. Smoked flavor, roasted, tar, dark chocolate, hops, perfume notes. Quite salty.

Bottled. Thx rlgk
Pitch black with a large dark beige head.
Smoked and slightly sourish aroma.
Very peaty and smoky flavour. Light bitterness.
Salty licorice and leather.

Poured into dimpled mug from 750ml bottle. Geek Bacon poured black with a dense and creamy brown head with excellent retention. Decent lacing left on the glass.

The aroma is very smoky with woody notes (I dont know what wood) prominent. It is like liquid campfire with an almost meaty feel to it. I guess that is where the bacon part comes from although it doesnt smell like bacon.

The taste is extremely smoky with lots of roasted malts. It also has elements of bitter coffee and wood. It is quite salty - almost like soya sauce.

It is medium bodied and quite smooth. Carbonation is moderate. Overall this was quite enjoyable (and quite rich). I great example of a smoked beer but I wouldnt rank it up there with Brunch Weasel and Beer Geek Breakfast on my personal charts.
Black with a dense brown head. Very smoky, like bonfire smoke and not really any smoked meat. Medium smoky roasty bitter.

500ml brown bottle. Pours black. Big column of thick brown foam on top. Aroma is predictably smokey/campfire, woody, even slightly meaty. Flavour has huge roasty malts, black coffee, salt, smoke, peat. Finishes with bitter smokey malts, black coffee and dark chocolate. Lingering coffee and smoked malt aftertaste. Silky full body, medium carbonation. Lots of bold, strong flavours but all are integrated well. Great beverage.

Bomber served in a tulip.  Pour is onyx with two fingers of thick, dark brown head that had decent retention and left a nice bit of lacing.  Nose is big smoke, roasted malt, salt, soy sauce, and dark chocolate.  Taste is smoke and roasted malt off the bat, then the soy sauce and dark chocolate kick in.  This backs off slightly and is joined by a lightly bitter finish.  This brew is interesting, but it is far from my favorite smoked brew, and I like the regular beer geek breakfast, or weasel, better.

Bottle.  Good beer, but I think I would lean towards having the regular beer more often.  Pours black with a large tan head.  Heavy heavy heavy smoke aroma and flavor.  Slight hops - the smoke overpower the coffee or chocolate I would normally find.  Good beer though.
Black pour with milkshake dark foamy head. Aroma is salty, bacon, peat, ash, nicotine. Flavor is sharpie pen, bacon, smoke, smoke, smoke, peat. Oddly, nice.

Ho-Wah! That is some smokey formaldahide smelling shiyat! I can only say that it seems to have been aged in barrels made from the wood used to smoke things, it is so damn smokey that no amount of liquid smoke would make a homebrew taste this good. Thick caramel and brown head on pour, very dark and smokey pretty nice creme lacing. I know there is the ususal Mikkeller hops in there, I can taste them, but the smoke is over top of it all. They should have called this the smokehouse, cuz theres no actual bacon in it, I could tell if there was... It is quite heavy on the palate, not quite a destroyer like but certainly and skewer. A very interesting beer study, though I think Id rather have the normal beer geek on a regular basis.

Tap at Cardinal. Black with a brown creamy film that lingers through the whole experience. Rich smokey and peaty nose - an aroma that expands with coffee, liqorice and other burnt and roasted notes in the mouth along with sweet and bitter flavors - even a hint of acidity. This is full bodied, medium carbonated thats smooth to drink and leaves a dry roasted finish that rides on bitterness. Another elixir from Mikkeller.

Black with a low foam
Aroma and flavour of BBQ. Got alittle Cola feel to it, angry carbonation. Medium body, okey lenght but the flavour falls in the end.
Summary: Had it once, it was okey
3/25/11. Bottle thanks to Tim! Black pour with a small brown head. Light smokey aroma of salt and beef. Subtle flavor of salty smoke and coffee, with a hint of ash. Quite nice, actually.

Aroma salt/sodium, bacon, coffee, roasty, hints of chocolate. Pour black with a nice caramel brown head. Taste coffee, chocolate with a great throat roastiness, then wam a nice hit of balanced smokiness, also a nice bit of bitterness. MF smooth creamy and velvety full body very faint fine carb. Great balanced beer not overly smokey terrific!!!

Liquid bacon? Sign me up! Poured out the usual totally black brew with a dark brown bubbly cap that, when poured properly, had a multishaded swirled crown. Sure it dies to a bit more than a rim clinger but thats ok. The aroma i just plain stupid. This is one of the most ridiculous smelling things poured out of a beer bottle that Ive ever smelt. This is the meatiest beer ever. Ive never even experience anything remotely close to this. Meat and salt - lots of salt. Saaaaaaaaaaalt. The salty smoke is awesome and totally dominating.  Deeper deeeeeepper inhalations bring forth touches of coffee and sharp something. I wish there was more depth here but, damn, if this meaty bacon saltfest isnt the shit! There is a slight sweetness and chocolatey smell in the distance. The taste is much better than the aroma as it is not so one dimensional. Bacon, meat, salt, yea obviously. Whats not as obvious: deep roast, hint of citrus, coffee goodness and bitterness, zippy and back of the throat bite, touch of chocolate, some harshness, spruce. Pretty much full bodied, good malts and bitterness that leave remnants in my mouth... which ruined. Im cured. Get it? Booo.

Bottle at home. Pours opaque black, thick dark tan head, stunning lacing. Really a gorgeous looking beer! Nose is big fudgy chocolate, combined with (unsurprisingly) a huge smoke component. This strikes me as more of a cured ham aroma than a fresh bacon one, but the smoke component is lovely nonetheless. Flavours are much smokier off the bat than the nose would suggest - Big hickory smoke character, plus the big mocha-stout character coming up behind it. As a "rauchbier", it fails, but it was never intended to be that, as a "Smoked Stout", I cannot fathom it turning out any better. A big win in my book!

On tap at Mikkeller Bar.

Could they improve on the weasel? Yes they can!

A super black pour with a light tan head. About three fingers of really nice puffy head, great carbonation, decent lacing...The aroma is simply outstanding with great balance and complexity. Starts off nice and smokey but balanced by bacon and just the right amount of coffee to cut into the smoke and not let it dominate like most smoked beers...The taste is just awesome as well, there is only a smoke accent that goes along with the great coffee flavor of the normal version, then the smoke comes back for a smokey finish, a totaly "backdraft" of smoke. 

This is an oustanding beer, cant say enough good things, search out and find this.

Sadly, from the bottle this has not come even close to the draft and the score reflects that.

The last part of our Beer Geek series, thanks to Tim and Rachel for the share. This really wasnt as smoky as I expected, slight coffee aroma underneath all the smoke. Its like breakfast in a glass. Quite nice.
On tap @ Cardinal, Stavanger. Pours black with good tan head. Bucketloads of roasted malts in here with a good hint of smoke. Not to much smokeyness, but enough to announce its presence.

In short: A roasted and smoky black beer with a true smoked bacon flavor.  Actually very nice.
How: Tap at Hill Farmstead Winter Gathering 2011
The look: Black body topped by a medium beige head with good retention
In long: Nose is very smoky, roasted, notes of espresso and yes some bacon.  Taste is roasted, plenty of caramel, usual coffee and black chocolate, earth, a lot of smoke, some beef jerky and yes some bacon.  Body is full and carbonation is lively.  Quite easy to drink actually.  I dont think it is because the name that I imagined the bacon taste.  I often find that some heavily smoked beers develop a bacon taste, but never to the extent of this beer.  Maybe they really used smoked bacon to make this beer.  That would be gross.  I dont wanna know, because some things you just dont want to know and also Im writing this rating completely naked.

Pours black with a very thick brown head. Aroma is very bold and smoky. It has that hickory smell like real bacon. Bold thick malty flavour, tones of chocolate and smoke. This is may be the most smoky beer I have ever tasted. It smells and tastes like sitting by the camp fire. I am instantly transported to the woods sitting around a camp fire enjoying the moon light. This is what beer geek bacon is doing for me. It is also very salty like a baltic porter. giving it that real bacon character. However, It has not lost the characteristics of the amazing stout on which it is based. The chocolate and coffee come through late in the palate lingering with the the smoke and salt. This is an amazing beer and very unique. I would be lying if I said I had not consider brewing a bacon flavoured beer myself. But, once again the people at mikkeller have done a very creative thing and pulled it off perfectly. This is one hell of a beer.

Bottle. Pitch black color, huge brown head. Smokey aroma of wood and bacon. Roasty taste with ash, more bacon and some coffee. Bitter finish and an oily texture leaving a dry taste in the mouth, which altogether makes this beer a meal in itself. Only thing missing is eggs.

Bottle... Poured black as night with an off-white head.  Big time smokey nose with peat and campfire.  Straight peat here all the way through.  I love smoked beers, but this was harsh for a full pour for me.  Bacon cooked over the campfire.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2013 500ml bottle labeled Rauch Geek Breakfast.

It pours into my snifter a thick dark absolute black with a foamy and glistening tan head. It is pretty basic, but also pretty nice to look at.

The smell is amazing. It has a thick coffee house scent over the top of deep and roasty malt scents. There is an abundance of sweet and dark chocolate in there as well. A bit of smoke can be smelled underneath. Again, it is pretty simple, each flavor can be picked out, it is very clean and precise.

The flavor packs a punch. Tons of coffee and roasty, smoky malts. It coats the tounge with flavor. The bitterness is up there, but overall it is in check. There is a wonderful sweetness underneath it all that keeps it all together. It has an alcohol presence for sure, but i isnt overpowering.

The mouthfeel is ultra thick and creamy. Perhaps too much so for my taste, though i may be in the minority here. The drinkability is surprising. I am quaffing this like nobodys business right now.

This is a powerful brew, and a delicious one at that.

I also made a burger to go with it, i caramelized some onions with some cane sugar, sherry, butter, olive oil, salt, pepper, and some bacon bits, mixed in some smoked mozzarella, then put a spoonful on an elk burger and covered that with a slice of smoked gouda. The flavor combo was out of this world.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-30-2010 23:42:11

Bottle from Oaktree from a while back. Pours out black with a thin tan head. Aroma is of roast, smoky meat, earth, and coffee. Taste is chocolate, coffee, earthy smoky notes, leather, jerky and some coffee notes int here also. Eventhough the beer itself contains no bacon, there is definitely that smoky, almost meaty characteristic of bacon in there. Two great things, beer and bacon, without actually putting bacon into the beer I guess this is as close as you get and for me it was a win.

Bottle at CP&K, Pimlico. It pours jet black with a thick bubbly tan head and moderate carbonation. The nose is dominantly smokey bacon, toast caramel, paint and a little mouldy. The taste is rich-roast coffee, caramel, toffee, oak, bacon, soy, burnt toast, liquorice and vinegar with a long smokey finish. I found this too savoury and nowhere near as balanced as beer geek breakfast. A bit of a let-down as I love bacon and beer geek breakfast as separate entities....

Pours dark rich black with thick tan head out of bottle.  Aroma is dominated by smoked meat and campfire, some salt, chocolate, and roast.  Taste is big smoky, campfire, roasted, with chocolate, salt, and coffee notes, finishing bitter with more smoke.  Deep and complex, if not covered up a bit by the intensity of the smoke.

Batch 489. Smoked roasted coffee-meat for sure. Black oil in the bottle. Medium light brown head. Surprisingly fresh non malty  light bitter taste. I can go with a little less smoke. Truly Homo Erectus with a grill.

Bottle, courtesy Beerlando. This was the US version labeled as Rauch Beer Geek. This one pours a nearly pitch black color and topped by a thick head of mocha colored foam that slowly recedes to a lasting film. Scattered patches of lace cling to the glass. The aroma is really nice and shows a strong base of bittersweet cocoa and roasted espresso. There is a touch of licorice followed by a smooth smoke component that livens things up. The smoke isnt too heavy or meaty as others are, and blends nicely with the roast and cocoa. The aroma follows with the rich bittersweet cocoa and dark roasted espresso forming the base. The smoke adds a nice earthy quality and a touch of smoothness, while burnt caramel adds just a touch of sweetness to balance all the roast. Nearly full bodied and smooth on the palate with balanced carbonation that leads to a lengthy mocha finish. This is some tasty stuff. This one is decadent with plenty of depth to the flavors. Really nice smoked stout.

At a tasting, many thanks DSG, 800th rating, pours black opaque with a nice chocolate head, aroma of chimney, wood, tobacco, beef jerky, smoked cheese and dark chocolate, flavor of burnt malt, charcoals, smoked fish, Turkish coffee, wine acidity, malt and nice bitterness, full bodied, excellent.

Bottle. Pours black as hell with a brown head. Dark roasted malt aroma, with smoke, coffee, and dark chocolate. The flavor has hard roasted malts, smoked malts, some bitter coffee notes, dark chocolate, and a lasting coffee finish. Awesome.

Draft @ Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and licorice aroma with smokey hints. Roasted malty chocolate licorice and some smokey flavor. Has a roasted malty chocolate and licorice finish with smokey hints in the aftertaste.

At a tasting, many thanks DSG, almost peach black, aroma of smoked wood, porcini, earth and a touch of balancing dark chocolate, flavour of dark chocolate, smoked wood and burned sugar, all the flavours are very intense and no alcoholic presence,  smooth and mouth coating. Wonderfull,wonderfull, wonderfull.

Bottle shared by John and Amy. The aroma is pretty phenolic with smoke, caramel, roast, and dark fruits. Taste is milk chocolate, harsh smoke, dark chocolate and smoldering campfire. The beer is rough throughout and the base beer is not well in integrated with the rauch malt, a difficult beer to drink.
Bottle from Bierkompass. Almost black color with thick beige head. Aroma, smokiness, wood. Taste, coffee, chocolate, bacon. Nice coffee bitter finish. Very nice beer.

Pours black with chocolate head - head is pretty hearty, bigger than a finger and sticks around for a good while. But I handwash my glasses and make sure there is no soap film.
Everything from the Beer Geek Breakfast is present - coffee, chocolate, with a hint that there is smoked malt in here. I was expecting big smoke in this one, but it seems good to balance as a subtlety instead of throwing it in your face.
Chocolate, vanilla, little coffee, little smoke, and hops. Again the smoke is just right. While I was hoping for actual bacon in a beer labeled "Beer Geek Bacon" I cant say Im disappointed I didnt find chunks of bacon floating around.
Velvety smooth, with a hint of bitterness. The smoke doesnt stick around like a real rauchbier, and that is a good thing - sometimes. Carbonation thins it out enough and brings the bitterness from the hops to the tongue after you swallow.
Very drinkable if you dont mind sleeping in a little late. The smoke is just subdued enough that you forget it is a smoked beer. But after a bit you remember that it is a decently strong beer. Good for a cold winter night with a big steak - from the grill of course. Or a smoked salmon. Mmmm. Just wish it had actual bacon. Then I could have it for breakfast with some eggs. Its got everything else you need in there.
Bottle.  Pours a deep brown, viscous with a creamy tan head that left some nice lacing.  Big smoke in the nose.  Some chocolate notes, spice, and smoke in the finish.
Love me a smoked stout, the bacon roastedness of the stout has to have a strong roasted malt profile that this stouts starts with. Highly recommended

Pours a dark brown/black with a huge dark brown head, great lacing .. . aroma of tar, chocolate, roast, and pure crispy bacon .. . touches of meat, bacon, tar, black molasses and coffee .. . i wanted more smoke but so complex and full, very nice brew- maybe needs six months/2 years to cool down a bit .. . I even like the name Bacon. You cant tell me the success of Kevin Bacon isnt somehow tied to his name. Youre not going out to see a Kevin Hot Dog movie. "Whos in this movie?" "Kevin Bacon." "Sounds good."

Grabbed a bottle of this at State Line.

Pours near black with a thing off white to tan head. Smell really brings out both the coffee and the smoke, which turns out to be a really lovely interaction. Taste is about the same, with a great competitive dynamic between the two. Nice amount of roasted malt in the background. Medium body with good carbonation; quite smooth. Drinks incredible well, especially for a smoked beer. Normally, 4oz. or so of something like that is already getting to be a bit much for me.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-06-2010

Bottle. Creamy lightbrown excellent fully lasting head. Black colour. Great heavy malty and moderate hoppy aroma. Strong roast, vanilla and smoked notes. Heavy bitter great chocolate flavor. Some smoked notes, but not dominating. Heavy bitter long finish. Creamy palate. very close to the perfect beer.

Pours a black color with a brown head.  Aroma is of chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, and some smokiness.  Thick on the palate with plenty of chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts.  Finishes with some smoke and a little bit of some alcohol warming.
bottle.  Pours black with a brown head.  Good lacing.  Nose is of smoked pork and burnt wood.  Taste is pork, wood and coffee.  Wow, this is delicious.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin.  Very good.

Bottle shared at the Black Friday tasting.  Pours pitch black with a small tan head.  The nose is asphalt, burnt plastic, coffee and smoke.  The taste is smoky wood, campfire coffee, burnt malt and ashy cocoa.  Medium bodied.  Nice stuff, but not as meaty as expected.

Aged for about 5 months after purchase. I really like the smokey flavor, probably the best smoked that I have had, neck and neck with Alaskan Smoked Porter. They dont over do it like some others. Pours jet black, bubbly and good. Actually has a nice head on it but that goes away. Nicely made, well done.

Bottle.  Pours a deep dark brown to black with a huge dense creamy mocha head.  Beautiful looking beer.  Gorgeous smoke and roast on the nose, big dark plum notes behind it.  Rich and inviting.  Lusciously smooth, cocoa and dark roast coffee coming through the subtle smoke.  Builds nicely to a long smokey, chocolate filled coffee finish.  Damned good stuff.  I was expecting a bit more smoke, but its really a nice touch to whats already an incredible beer.

12 oz. bottle in a lager glass.  Had to try because I loved Beer Geek Breakfast.  Didnt realized it was smoked, but now Im not upset about that at all.  The only other smoked Ive had was Shiners Smokehaus.  There is no comparison.  Opaque black pour with nice frothy brown head.  Strong nutty aroma.  Very rich, but not overbearing.  Smoke flavor comes through very well.  Not at all what I was expecting, but again, this is Mikkeller, not Shiner.  Incredible, delicious beer.

On tap at Ørsted. 
Pours a pitch black colour with a firm dense brown head. 
Aroma is heavy roasted malt, smoke, coffee, liquorice and tobacco. 
Flavour is roasted malt, smoke, tar, tobacco, liquorice and coffee. Lightly bitter and quite smoky with a rather thin body.

Deep brown pour.  Sticky brown-tan head.  The nose is a little bit soft and smokey.  Softly leathery on the nose with a little bit of sticky leathery cocoa character.  Chewy and softly salty as well.  A little bit of ashy character.  Light molasses and a whiff of soft chewy character.  A bit of lovely rich intense earthiness.  Its nice, but I dont really get a whole lot of smoke.  The bitterness is a bit astringent as well.

Courtesy of ken1. Black with a large and lasting dark brown head. Aroma is hard roasted malt, coffee, ashy and lots of smoke. The smoke is not really bacon or ham like you can find in the Schlenkerlas but rather a peated smoke. The flavor is quite sweet and the body is heavy. The finish is roasted bitter and dry. 230111
Very good beer with a smokey flavor. Good colour and nice foam. A good version of the beer geek series.

On tap at Firkin in Libertyville, IL. Pours a black body with an inch thick, very dense and creamy, dark brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma has tons of smoked malts and peat with a really nice roast behind. Some hops make their way in as this warms along with a bit of a chocolate maltiness. Flavor is similar. A light chocolate malt up front before tons of smoked peat comes in. Again, a nice roast alongside the smoked malts as well as a distinct, but subtle earthy and somewhat piney hopping. Finishes dry with a moderate, roasty and hoppy bitterness along with tons of smoke and peat that leaves a very lengthy, almost salty aftertaste. Medium-full, smooth body and a moderate, almost creamy carbonation. Overall, a very nice beer. Lots of smoke and peat, but plenty of roasts and well hopped at the same time. Malts keep this nicely balanced and it drinks very well. Damn, this was good.

500ml bottle (Bierkompass.de)
7 Undeniably pleasant aroma - rich smoky malts, a touch on the wooly side rather than the bacony side. Coffee clear but not prominant.
4+ Black, dark head, a little fizzy and brief. Would have been a 5 were it not for the coffee killing the head retention.
7+ Stonking rich roasty taste, gentle coffee component, nicely balanced, but a little too dark and roasty, lacking the big quaffability of the weasel.
4+ Again, very full, but a touch on the sticky side. Pleasant carbonation. Finish on the burnt side of roast. Leaves the mouth and the lips coated with stickiness, not saying "drink me Ill quench yout thirst". Which is a shame, as it covers the 7.5% brilliantly.
15+ A whisker short of brilliance, this is just very good. Do pour carefully, as once you let the crud (bottom 10-15%) across, youre up for a much more slimy experience. However, do pour the slime out too at the end, as, even though it sounds disgustng as it plops out of the bottle, it all tastes good.

On draught @ The Porter.  Black pour with a big dark brown head.  Aroma was overly smoky, like burnt toast, char.  Subtle bits of roast and cocoa made their attempt to come through, unsuccessful.  Just smoky dark malts.  Flavors were also just as one dimensional.  Like sticking your head in a big pork smoker.  I dont understand these super smoked brews, they are just too one sided for me.  It seems like someone is enjoying them though...

Black pour with a chocolate color brown head. Aroma is smoke and chocolate with a touch of bacon and chili peppers. Flavor is roasty coffee, chocolate and chilis, but not a lot of bacon.  Still very good stuff!

500 ml bottle via an international trade conducted on national soil at PUBN secret headquarters nestled somewhere in suburban Philadephia.  Pours ruddy tirbid deep blackish brown with big 3-finger tan head into a snifter.  Nose is rauchy black patent malt, molasses, cacao, salt.  Tastes dry, rauchy, black patent malty, with notes of saliney hops, coffee, and damn if I don;t get an oily pork undercurrent here.  Complex and very flavorful, this one would terrify someone not used to innovative craft beer, but for the grizzled veterans it is a true pleasure.  Gets VERy dry and smokey and resiny hoppy as it warms.

500mL bottle.  Poured deeper brown with garnet highlights.. short-lived, swirly beige head.  The aroma picked up a lovely dose of smoked hardwoods and peat, with coffee and chocolatey notes deeper down.. the smoked malts really stand out.  The flavor opened with warm, thick coffee and molasses malts, with more molasses plus honey on the middle.. the smoked malts take a little time to sink in, but are in full force by the finish.. saltiness plus sweeter, roasted coffee on the back-end.. overall a little heavy-handed with the smoke, and a little too sweet, but still very tasty.  Medium-bodied and a little syrupy on the palate.. lower carbonation.. kind of thick on the back with heavy sweetness and smoke.  Interesting stuff, but I liked the original more.

500ml bottle. Shared with some friends, and thank goodness for that, because finishing this bottle by myself would have been tough. Dark syrupy pour with a thin bubbly brown head. Smokey aroma with hints of wood, malts, and hops. With flavors like smoke, wood and malts it was pretty heavy on the palate, but  I was able to pull through like a champ. Very interesting and surprisingly delicious.

500mL bottle in a mini Duvel tulip glass. Not sure why you would brew a smoked Oatmeal stout and then fill it full of hops.  Thats probably my biggest complaint, the two aspects get in the way of each other.  The flavor also has a very mineral finish taking away from the overall profile of the beer.   Its a beautiful dark brown , big ass, head atop a black body.  The mouthfeel is great as well, thick, velvety, and viscous.  If only the flavor of the beer was better, you got hops, smoke, sweet stout, and a pretty good amount of residual sugars all mixed together.  Its not off-putting but its too scatterbrained.  Also, not nearly enough smoke as I would want from this beer, probably because its overshadowed by all of those other flavor elements.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: On tap at fountainhead. Black with thick tan head. Aroma is smoky. Flavor is smoky and chocolate. Nice, long, light smoky finish. Delicious.

Pitch black. Thick creamy head - dark mocha color.  Roasted malts. A lot of coffee upfront and little smokiness.  Roasted barley, and some sweetness. Coffee, plum, and that brown sugar note. Mild hop bitterness on the backend.  Medium to fuller body, but it feels only slightly loose (not watery at all). Theres a little be of mouth coating that lingers a bit.  Very smooth.
(500ml bottle thanks to bu11zeye) near espresso, ruby clear edges. Nose of bacon fat, great campfire smoke. Taste is very smokey, fudge, awesome richness. Creamy body.

Bottle bought at De Molen and drank at home on New Years Eve 2010/11.  Intense black beer with a thick tan head.  Some smoke, but mostly big intense coffee and dark choc and oatmeal.  Intense oily mouthfeel.  Long lasting espresso and dark choc finish.  Huge, massive beer that is likeable and drinkable at the same time whilst I want to just sit here and sip it.  I love the coffee on this.  Really terrific.  Yes a little smoke carries on through, but no where near to some of the Bamberg rauchs but that isnt a problem with me.  Took me an hour to drink it was that intense and I enjoyed the aftertaste so much.  Yep, well that is a hell of a beer.

Sampled on 12/18/2010. This smoked beer pours an eclipse black color from a 50cl bottle. Medium sized tan foamy head with nice retention and good lacing. The aroma is smoke, roasted malt, vanilla and chocolate. Medium bodied smoked stout. The malts are chocolate and coffee, smoked and semi sweet. The hops are earthy. A touch sweet and smoky. Very smoky, but its not to the liquid bacon stage. Touch of oatmeal fullness in the mouthfeel. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet and smoky.

Bottle.  Pours a black body with a light tan head.  Smokey body with smoked malt tones, smoked meats, light bacon and salt tones.  Campfire a hint of ash, light espresso bitterness and a thick body with little warmth.  A solid offering from Mikkeller.
(bottled and shared with oh6gdx) almost deep black colur with nice brown head. coffee coffee and more coffee. not much else. coffee. this aint good .(

Bottled (from Kihosk, Copenhagen, if my memory works). Black colour, mediumsized brown head that leaves good lace. Aroma is coffee, roasted malts and a bunch of ashes. Flavour is coffee, roasted malts, mild bacony fat, ashes as well as some mild alcohol. Too roasted and ashy for my taste.

Pitch black coloured body with an oily, deep brown head with a completely opaque black glow. Aroma of what youd expect - smoked meat, peat, coffee, licorice and a ton of alcohol and roasted malt. Full-bodied; Deep pungent smoked peat and bacon flavour with a lot of licorice, sweet flavours and a good potent alcohol taste. Aftertaste is strong and full of complexity with the pungent bacon and licorice tastes staying the longest. Overall, a nice beer - definitely a good smoked beer with some good flavours and complexity. I sampled this 50 cL bottle labeled as Rauch Geek Breakfast purchased from Liquor Outlet in Boonton, New Jersey on 21-November-2010, sampled at home in Washington on 26-December-2010.

Bottle... Pours black with a small, short-lived, creamy, brown head. Dark chocolate and campfire smoke are the aromatic standouts. Full-bodied and mildly creamy with fizzy carbonation. The flavor supplies deep, dark, Cuban espresso, smoked meat, carbonaceous bitterness and mild dark chocolate sweetness. Lengthy, bitter, acrid finish. Bottle courtesy of Plovmand!

Pours black into a tulip. Micro mocha head with excellent retention fills glass and slowly recedes leaving spot lacing. Smoke and mocha aromas. Thin with light smoked chocolate from front to back.  Lasting smoky espresso finish.

Bottle; poured a dark brown/black color; quite thick looking.  Small to medium light brown head.  Aroma of smoked malt, oats, meat, leather, and earth.  Flavor had a lot of roasted oats, coffee, meat, and of course smoked oats.  Dry and earthy.  Surprisingly easy to drink.  Lingering finish.  Quite tasty.

50 cl bottle, pours dark with a lovely creamy head that has very solid retention, slight lacings, aroma of peat, smoke, roasted coffee and chocolate, taste follows the nose, medium body, solid lingering  finish, nice beer.

50cl bottle pours an oily, opaque black with a creamy, tan head.  Nose of burnt rubber, light malt, nutty, bready, toast, chocolate.  Flavor is sweet, brown sugar, chocolate, light smoke, malty, lightly bready.  Full bodied, sweet, smokey finish.  Well balanced.  They took a great base beer and tweaked it nicely.

Pours a deep, deep dark brown color that appears pitch black in the glass. Completely opaque without even the slightest hint of lighter color when held to a light source and a frothy three finger mocha colored head. Excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that coats the glass with large chunks of soapy lacing.

Very smokey malt aroma with hints of silky chocolate malt, roasted coffee/espresso bean, oatmeal and burnt toast complimenting the usual smoke/rauchbier notes. Hints of campfire, butane, ash, charcoal and BBQ bacon. The smokiness in the aroma isnt as extreme as I had hoped but its still pretty intense.

Chewy medium body with a very bitter, roasty smoked malt flavor that dominates throughout into a long dry finish. This beer is also surprisingly hop forward adding to the roasty bitterness. Silky chocolate malt and a creamy lactic presence add balance to the smokiness. Im also picking up hints of oatmeal roasted coffee bean, burnt toast and toffee. Again, as in the aroma, its not as intensely smokey as I expected but the usual burnt malt, charcoal, bacon, BBQ and charred notes are still evident.

Overall, this beer is more well balanced than I prefer for this style but the surprising hop character is quite nice.

Bomber thanks to Santa. Pours a pure black color with a medium brown head. A sweet smoky and hoppy nose with some roast. The flavor is very good; rich heavy smoke, some roast, light dark fruit, quite hoppy, some bitterness. Nice.

Bottle.  Pour is deep brown with a medium light brown head.  Aroma is smoked malt, light mat, and faint sweetness.  Flavor true to nose with lots of smoke and a faint sweetness.  Slightly lighter than expected body.

22oz bottle shared by doug, thanks 
Appearance: Black with a medium dark tan head and lots of lacing 
Aroma: Ashy, smokey and dark malts 
Taste: Smokey, dark malts and grainy 
Nice. Lots of smokey aroma and flavor, but not overdone.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Pours black with a bubbly tan head. Smells like bacon. Irony. Taste has a slight hop note at first, and transitions quickly into a smoky/bacon flavor. Has a nice complexity on the palate, and the taste has a good finish (bacon doesnt linger) considering the bacon is present through 90% of the experience.

Hyvin musta, ruskealla vaahdolla varustettu olut kätkee sisäänsä yllättävän miedon savuaromin. Pekoni jää itselläni hieman kadoksiin myös. Aromi on silti miellyttävän suklainen, kahvinen ja paahtunut. Suutuntuma on suorastaan samettisen pehmeä. Maun paahtuneet maltaat, kahvi ja suklaa luovat tutun ja miellyttävän yhdistelmän. Humalointi on jotenkin raikasta ja ruohoista ja jopa kukkaista, mikä on myös hieman yllättävää. Bacon kuuluu savuoluiden kärkikaartiin.

Bottle. Pours a deep black color with a decent tan head. Kinda smells like bacon with some sweet malt in the background. Baconesue taste with some roasted malt a hint of coffee in the background. Very interesting! I like what they did with it. Great combo and balance.

Pours black with a thick coffee colored head. Aroma is of bacon, some sweet malts, and a slight touch of hops. Flavor is slightly hoppy at first and transitions into a smoky/malty/bacon finish. Very interesting and a lot more... meaty?... than other smoked beers Ive had. Actually a mellow finish for being so filled with bacon.
Bottle from bu11zeye.  Dark brown pour with a small brown head.  Aroma is smoked sausage, almonds, and chocolate.  Taste is more barbeque, chocolate, and pepper.

Bottle purchased at Blacklick Wine & Spirits. Black pour with a medium light brown head. Smoky aroma with coffee and chocolate. Flavor starts with smoke, then moves to chocolate before a roasty coffee finish. Very well done smoke beer thats not overly hammy.
bottle, thanks to bu11zeye, black brown pour with tan foam, aroma is coffee, roast malt, woodfire, flavors are coffee, tobacco, roast malt, ashy, astringent tea like

Bottle courtesy bu11zeye. Heavy brown color with some brown head. Aroma is bacon smoke with heavy malts and roast. Flavor is heavy smoke, dry roast and beef jerky flavor that goes on through the finish. Decent but very dry.

Bottle shared by StFun at BASC - thanks, Josh! The regular ol BG and even the Weaz are delicious for the coffee stout freaks. Was very intrigued to try the rauched up version and thought it was great. Thick black pour with a solid tan head and nice lacing. Nose is really lovely, with the thick malts one expects but supplemented with a different roasted additions, of the porktastic rather than beanalicious variety. Velvety mouthfeel, creamy with a slightly dry finish. Taste is really nice, like a more brash AKS.

bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  poured black with a dark khaki head.  nose is heavy on the bbq, smoke, roasted malts, and light chocolate.  great on the palate, nice flavor of roasted malts, smoke, and bbq, great stuff.

16.9 oz bottle. Bought this at my liquor store before I even figured out that"Rauch Geek Breakfast" was the bacon version. Now Im ecstatic to try it. Pours a completely opaque oil black with a small brown head that dies quickly. Smells of a ton of coffee, a hint of oats, and what might be a LOT of smoke (unless its part of the bacon aspect). A little intimidated prior to the first taste by how much smoke is in the aroma, but it actually doesnt affect the taste that much. The oats become more noticeable, the coffee is a bit more subtle, and the smoke is still there (but not too strong). Not sure I get the bacon aspect of it, and I think I like the regular Beer Geek Breafast more, but overall a very good beer.
(500ml bottle)  Pours an opaque black body with a small brown head.  Aroma of smoke, coffee, roasted malt, and chocolate. Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, smoke, and chocolate with a dry finish.

A black colored beer, with a thick foamy brown head. The aroma of smoke, bitter and coffee malts. The taste of bitter coffee, somke and dry. Notes of chocolate. The aftertaste is bitter, some sweet and strong coffee notes.

Bottled. The aroma has coffee, chocolate, roast and smoked meat. Black coloured beer with a lasting, off-white head. The taste is a bit sweet, has bitterness, chocolate, coffee, roast and smoke. Medium bodied beer. Nice balance. Good one.

Bottle looks great, the beer in the glass also. Deep black, creamy head. Starts very malty, heavy, a bit oily almost, modest smoky. Smoky notes disappear fast, finish well balanced, malty-dry, little bit alcoholic. Smoky notes could be more intense, but still a great beer! Thanks to yespr for the bottle!
Dark dark brown, tan ring.  Aroma is roast, smoky, meat, light vegetal bit.  Taste is more roast, smoky, chocolate, light meatiness.
Poured very black, coffee, smoke, peat, chocolate, little bacon, slight licorice.

Bottled.  Very black, creamy beige head. Lightly smokey with some licorice. Sweet with full body and rather creamy moutfheel. Slight smoke behind the coffee, followed by a tarry finish. Feels solid, but leaves less impressed than I was hoping for.
Pours a brown with a brown head. Aroma is smoke and chocolate malt. Flavor is chocolate malts, smoke, espresso. Not as bacony as I"d expect, but the smokiness is just about right for me. Nice brew.

500ml bottle from Binnys Downtown in Chicago.  Pours dark brown/black with a sizable and lasting darker tan head.  Aroma is a nice combination of meat and campfire smoke, light peat, espresso, a little chocolate and some general heavily roasted malts.  Flavor is more smoke, peat, espresso and light chocolate.  Not over the top complex, but delivers well as a great smoked.  Wish this was available locally as Id grab another bottle or two for the winter.

Bottle poured an opaque dark brown nearly black with a lasting brown head. Aromas of milk chocolate, smoke, coffee, roasted malt, light vanilla, light bacon and a hint of licorice. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of milk chocolate, smoke, coffee, roasted malt, light vanilla, light bacon and a hint of licorice with a smooth lingering smokey finish.

Bottled 50cl. Ordered from www.bierkompass.de. Complex. Oats are pretty apparent in the taste. Smooth and smoky. Some sweetness. Not bothering to write more. Delicious and flawless but far from being fantastic.

Bottle from Wallys. Nicely smokey aroma, its fairly bacony. Some coffee ground, less chocolate. More chocolate as it warms. Finish is awesome. Some hop flavor and plenty of hop bitterness. A very small bit of metal flavor.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is malt, coffee, hop, cocoa, smoked, malt. Flavour is coffee, hop, smoked, malt, cocoa, malt, licorice, alcohol. Full body. Very nice beer.

Bottle home. Thanks Papsoe in advance but your bottle is reserved for a mate. 

Awesome full mocha lacing, opaque and jet black tone on appearance, aroma is peat, chocolate, smoke, coffee and vanilla. Taste is full on,no teasing here, pure anarchy, great espresso bitterness, chocolate, vanilla, coffee, so incredibly guey and stunningly so, rich roasted malts, some nicely balanced hops, not too much, hazlenut on the palate, or maybe some bacon fat?? Finish is medium and coffee and roasted. Music score to drink with - Bacon Fat. By the legend which is Andre Williams. Great work Mikkeller. Gorgeous.

Tasted on draft at Local Option.  Pours black with a thick tan head that leaves heavy lace.  Surprise, surprise, the nose is super smoky bacon combined with a very roasted dark malt.  The flavor features the roasted malt and has an added fig flavor with the smoky bacon taking over on the back of the palate.  The body is full with average carbonation and a long roasted finish

Served from a 22oz bottle from OTM. The appearance is a deep glossy flat black with a big brown head. The aromas are full of smoked oatmeal. The flavors are bacon/smoked malts, oatmeal, coffee grinds. The mouth is medium to full bodied. Very medium bubbled carbonation. Another nice Mikkeller breakfast stout.

Pours black with a large dark brown head. Very oily as it pours into the glass. It seems bigger than it is. The aroma is beautiful with charred wood, smoke, salty, coffee, and dark chocolate in the background. Smells like breakfast at a campground! Love it. Low carbonation and a silky mouthfeel with lots of roasted malts and smoke. Pretty dry in the finish. Full bodied. Great beer, and my favorite smoked to date!

Sampled at Lithys Tennessee/Ole Miss tasting.  Thanks lithy.  Unfortunately, does not live up to the bacon name.  Lots of roast. Good imp stout, but not bacony in the least.   Could have been so much more.

500ml bottle from Discount Liquor. Pours black with tan head and lacing. Aromas of coffee, smoke, and roasted malts. Flavors of lots of smoke, bacon, light maple syrup, coffee, and fair amount of roasted malts. Finishes dry and roasty with bitter coffee and smoke lingering on the tongue. May be the best smoked beer I have had.

50cl traded bottle. Pours a jet black color with a medium brown head and a little lacing. Big aroma of hickory, menthol smoke, honestly bacon, and sweet syrup. Maybe a little chocolate too. Fun flavor where the smokiness and bacon appears at the end. Almost more flavors in this beer than I can accurately describe here. Cool concept, done well.
Draught at the bar. Low lasting light brown head. Pitch black body. Mild coffee smoke bacon aroma and flavor with low carbonation and a long aftertaste.

Vigorous pour produces a huge, thick and healthy brown head.  Aroma is heavy, dry smoke over roasted malt.  Smells f-ing awesome with a dry, ashy quality running through the initial smoke and the roasted malt.  Taste is smokey bacon with hops bitterness toward the final 1/3 and a dry finish.  The initial taste is somewhat thin but Im not sure that youd really want a thicker stout with the smoke influence.  Very tasty.

Bottle. Blackish bee with a brown head. Bacon/smoke aroma with coffee and sweet malt. Malt and chocolate flavor with coffee and light salty smoke. Medium bodied. Chocolate and coffee linger with smoke and malt.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black color with a frothy tan head. Aroma is of meaty smoke like bacon and smoked ham, i also get roasted malt and coffee. But the smoke is what dominates the aroma. Flavor is of a small amount of hops, coffee, a slight burnt note and roasted malt. In the finish you get the smoke and the meaty smoke flavors of bacon and smoked ham. The body is medium to full with a nice creamy mouthfeel. Overall a really nice Smoked Stout, but it didnt impress me as much as the regular Beer Geek Breakfast did. But its certainly better than the Beer Hop Breakfast!

truly outstanding.  incredible aroma of smoke/ham/bacon.  flavor is so complex. moderate to high smokiness with coffee underneath, works together just beautifully. think smoked imperial stout. i love black coffee and bacon but the way this comes together is just out of this world.

Pitch black pour with a huge tan head that never seems to leave ever. The aroma is huge smoke- massive creamy lactic sugars, milk chocolate, bitter roasted cocoa nib, salty brine, oatmeal, mild booze, whiskey barrel oak, and peat. The flavor holds massive roasted malts, cocoa nib, the strongest of espresso, and bakers chocolate. Smokey malts dont come through as powerfully as the aroma would suggest, but literally provide a perfect complement to the beer geek base beer. Peaty whiskey barrel abounds. The palate is massively thick, rich, viscous, and silky. Dry roasty finish.

Bottle labeled "Rauch Geek Breakfast." Absolutely gorgeous pour-- black as night with a big, thick light brown head. Aroma is simply divine; tons of creamy lactic sugar, heavy, milk chocolate, bitter roasted malts, briny smoked pork, and a touch of oatmeal. Caramel or molasses is basically non-existent, which I love; the sweetness is contained in the lactic character. Faintest touch of booze as well. Flavor is wondrous as well. Coffee, roasted malt, and dark chocolate become much more pronounced. I get a bit of sweet chocolate cake in there, but the bitterness from the dark roast is delightful-- fantastic contrast. The smoke is a bit more subtle than on the nose, but still evident and more than welcome. Even some notes of peat come through on the tongue. Palate is so intriguing because you feel like this will be an impy, but the palate is so light and easy. Fantastic stuff.
Bottle from Salling, Århus. Huge tan head with excellent duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are rich roast malt, chocolate, smoke and coffee. Excellent beer.

A pitch black, viscous brew with a very heavy, creamy dark tan head. Nose has a strong burn oak presence followed by a sweet caramel, strong chocolate, mild coffee and finishes off with a generic ashen kick reminiscent of the remnants of a bonfire the night after a big party. Flavor of the brew is pretty complex with a more dominant burnt flavor that sticks to your tongue and wrestles it while more modest notes of coffee, dark chocolate and heavy roasted malt make their way to your palate.  Body is modestly heavy with a light feeling and low carbonation. Overall not too bad of a brew. The smoke flavor definitely adds a rounded feeling to it.

,5 L bottle

This pours dark brown with a frothy tan head and leaves a lot  of lacing.
The flavor has notes of smokiness, used coffee grounds and finishes with some lactic sourness.
Black colored brew with a nice brown head. Aroma is smoky, very smoky. Flavor is full of ashy smoke, coffee and bitter chocolate. Nice addition. Doesnt feel like 7,5% at all, big beer.

Pours a dark black color with a caramel colored head.  Has an aroma of smoke and coffee with hints of dark fruit and caramel.   Has a sweet smoky taste with some bitters and dark fruit on the finish.   Creamy.  Tasty.

(Bottled) Almost black with medium-brown head. Very roasted nose with sweet smoked maltiness for balance. Flavor is initially slightly burned and very roasty, and the smokiness only comes along in the aftertaste - even then not very strongly. Some coffee and notes of licorice, too. I would have liked more smokiness in the flavor to balance the roastiness, but even like this its quite good. 4446

500 ml bottle. Batch #489, brewed 11.03.2010.
Pours a pitch black colour with a large, foamy, blackish brown colour. Rich aroma of roasted malts and burnt coffee with some smoke notes. Flavour of smoked and roasted malts with mild hops and extremely dry coffee. Very dry finish. Full bodied, oily texture and dry mouthfeel. Pleasant.

500ml bottle from Bierkompass

Pretty nicely balanced stout/smoked hybrid. Great roasted and smoked aroma.

Black with the typical great head. Lots of smoke in the aroma. A little ashy. Just a touch of raisin. The flavor is more balanced with lots of hard roast and some charred wood. Medium bodied and creamy. Pretty bitter through the finish with lots of coffee, roast, and smoke. A little acidic as well. Just toO harsh overall.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2014 The Aroma is so nice defined with the BBQ bacon thing. The taste is like the original beer geek but with added smoke, a bacon-feel and soul. I was a little bit skeptical, but this turned out really good!

The aroma of delicous bacon smoother than normal for a smoked beer. It pours very dark with a beautiful creamy cappuccino head. The flavor of.a smoked beer that is creamy, smooth, and so easy to drink. There are nice coffee and smoky notes as well.

bottle: Rauch Geek Breakfast.
aroma is mostly smoke, very malty and roasty, with smoked meat / bacon apparent. theres also some wood, alcohol, and vanilla.
pours opaque brown with thick frothy brown head that dissipates very quickly.
flavor is sweet with smoke bite and long smoked meat finish.
medium-heavy body, slightly astringent.

On tap at Churchkey.  Definitely enjoyed this one.  didnt taste a ton of bacon in it, but theres a ton of smoke and a great stout behind it.  Great hops, perfect mouthfeel and a good body and finish.  Some people know how to make stouts, and these guys are in that group.  Good stuff.

500ml bottle @Jimmack Invitational Thanks jtclockworkpours a dark brown head and black color.  Aroma is rich/roasty/molasses-dark malt/oat.  Taste is rich/roasty/molasses-dark malt/oat, some acidic hops.

Pours a dark dark brown color that may border on black.  Nice brown head that is a medium in size and not as stable as I would like.  Smells of burnt coffee, non burnt coffee, chocolate, a smoldering fire, some wood and a bit more burnt taste.  Taste is fairly smokey and burnt.  I taste some burning wood, some green grass that has been lit on fire and is smoking, some chocolate, very burnt coffee, and more burnt wood!  Fairly bitter taste with the burnt and smokey flavors really blasting the palette at the end of this drink.  I do not taste the bacon flavor that I was hoping for with the title of this one but that is probably a good thing.  As much as I like bacon, it might be weird in a beer.  But who knows!

bottle.  black under medium, brown head.  aroma is mostly chocolate with a bit of charred meat.  flavor has the same charred, burnt meat, smoke with bitter dark chocolate malt.  really dry finish.  full body.  its ok so.. sa da tay.  cole me on the panny sty - pootie tang
bottle at home ... deep black ... thin tan head ... deep malt .... soft smokey nose ... light roast malt body ... soft dark roast ... light smoke ... little toffee ...

Bottled. Pours opaque black beer and a nice light brown head. Fair lacings. Nose of smoke, hard roasted malt and coffee. Flavour with roasted malt, coffee, ash and dark chocolate.Full bodied. Oily texture.  Ends up more. Excellent but very similar to the other geek brews except the smoke.

ketchepillar was so kind as to bring this back from halfway across the country. Pours a deep black with a very small head (if I swish the snifter) this however does leave some lacing, surprisingly enough. The aroma is sweet smoked bacon with some coffee, and plenty of roastiness. I didnt detect much for hops at all in the aroma of this beer which is why I am surprised that the beer has as much fruity hop character in the flavor as it does. The flavor is of course dominated by sweet smoked bacon and cocoa with some nice fresh roasted coffee. The finish is remarkably clean, and for a beer with this much going on thats really saying something. Just a really tasty beer.

Bottle.  Pours a dark, thick motor oil black with a dark tan head.  Lots of smoke and roasted malt initially, and some peat and earthiness.  I expected a bit more of a meat-driven smoke, but its still damn good.  Definitely smokey in the taste, but nice dark bittersweet chocolate, sharp bitter coffee, and a very roasted/smokey finish.  Thicker body, with bubbly carbonation, nice and viscous, and a bit silky.  Damn good.

On tap at Palm Tavern during Milwaukee beer week.  Midnight black with a medium tan head.  Aroma of heavily smoked malts, peat, campfire, liquid fire and light bacon.  Taste is smoky, salty and sweet.  Heavily roasted with some peatiness to complement the meatiness.  Smooth with a sweet smoky finish.  One snifter (split) is more than enough as I can see the law of diminishing returns rearing its head on this one.

500ml bottle. Poured a dark black color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of smoke (not over powering), oats, chocolate, ashes, some meatiness, and caramel. Tastes of chocolate, roast, smoked meats, vanilla, some earthiness, and coffee.

500 ml bottle from Friar Tuck in Crestwood.  Pours an opaque black color with a small brown head.  Aroma of campfire, smoked pork, oats, roast, coffee, and chocolate.  Flavor of dark roasted coffee, smoked meat, toasted brown sugar, metal, and cocoa.  Ashy finish.  I like what the smoke is doing here.  Medium-full bodied, with medium carbonation and a roasty mouthfeel.

Bottled. Dark color, thick brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, smoke, bacon, hint of rye and licorice, peat. Bit bitter taste, roasted, hint of woody bourbony notes, but thats probably the combination of smoke and roasted malts (whisky malt?) instead of true barrel aging. Thick creamy texture, but also good balanced carbonation. Slight dry. Lovely smoked beer.

Bottle, pours black with foamy tan head. Big beechwood smoke aroma with oats, ash, and cocoa powder undertones. The taste has some harsh cigar ash and beechwood smoke while astringent chocolate malts and coffee roun it out. Med body, just finishes too ashy for my taste and I cant figure out while its $3-4 more than reg BGB.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2010 Thanks peter for sharing.   Nice clean. Smoked salmon, earthy campfire, and toasty chocolate.  Taste is clean fresh cocoa and coffee.   Liked this better than regular.    Awesome smoke character.  Tight coffee presence in the taste.  Liked this quite a bit.  Awesome beer!  Exceeded expectatiomns.

Bottle: Pours a Dark Black, with a thick and creamy beige head. Decent retention and lacing. Huge malt aroma initially, with a hint of smoke. I get far more of the bitter coffee laced oatmeal stout over the smokiness, but those elements are obviously there in muted form. Flavors are big chocolate cocoa malts, a bit of roasted coffee,  dark chocolate, and at the tail end of hint of smokiness and hops. As some other people have stated, the rauch elements are really muted here - If they were going for drinkability, i think they succeeded - but I find it slightly dissapointing. As an oatmeal stout though its a fantastic beer in and of itself, so dont get me wrong.

Serving: 600 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors. 
Aroma: The nose is a nice mix of smoke, nuts, a bit of band aid, peat, and a touch of ham. 
Appearance: It pours black with slight ruby highlights and a dense, tan head. 
Taste: The flavor is a nice mix of a dry stout and a smoked beer.  There are notes of black coffee, cigarette smoke, smoked ham, peat, and earth. 
Palate: It has a medium to rich body with lower than average carbonation and a lingering burnt and smokey finish. 
Overall: An outstanding example of a smoked beer with a twist.  Recommended!

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2010 On tap @ Henrik, Bergen. Pours a black body with a light, foamy caramel head. Smell is leather, burnt toast and coffee, with hints of smoke. First sip: strong, almost astringent bitter burnt toasty notes, some hops in the background. Coffee and hints of smoke comes around in the aftertaste. A relatively light body heightens drinkability, but I miss the kind of roasty meat flavor that usually goes with a rauch; Im just not feeling it here. Wheres the bacon? The smoke and ashes? The cured meat or tobacco? On a second note: the tap at Henriks is probably a tad bit too cold; the beer does pick up in flavor after a while, but not quite enough. A bit of a disappointment really, I had high hopes for this one.

Dark black pour w/ a whispy dark brown head and thick lacing.
Lightly smoky aroma a hint of salty smoked meat I guess it could be bacon but if it is its still really light.  Then a lot of rich deep malts some light dark fruits, chocolats, hints of roasty coffee are really light in the background.  Full well coated palate.
Reminiscant of a rausch beer, lightly smoky hints of salt in the taste, though I dont get much meat or bacon really.
Goes well w/ a big hunk of meat though.
Pretty good.

On tap at Henriks, Bergen, Pours pitch black with a small creamy brown head. Strong roasted malty aroma, coffee and smoked bacon. Taste is the same roasted malts, with a minor smoked character which I think suits this beer very well.Big malty body. Taste is more smoked than the aroma suggest, thats for sure.Smooth mouthfeel. Long bitter end, lovely beer

Bottle. Poured an opaque dark brown color with a thick brown head that reduced to a thin film after a few minutes. Smelled of tar, dark chocolate, and subdued smoke. Medium to full bodied and delicately sweet with mild to moderate bitterness that lingered. Roasty and somewhat smoky with a hint of alcohol warmth in the belly. Flavors followed the aroma.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2011 Re-rate 2/21/11: Bottle shared at a tasting. black with a big brown head. Burnt aroma, slightly vinous, with coffee. Roasty flavor, somewhat smoky, with some chocolate, coffee notes and a bitter roasty finish. Full-bodied. Excellent. 7/4/8/4/16=3.9

[9/26/10] Draught at Beer Temple in Amsterdam. Black with a bubbly brown head. Aroma of espresso, some smoked wood and some dark chocolate hints. Sweet, somewhat smoky flavor with some coffee, dark chocolate and meaty hints. Medium-full-bodied. 7/4/8/4/15=3.8

Jet black pour with a big, frothy, brown head.  Lots of espresso roasted coffee bean aroma with a healthy dose of dark chocolate, mild dark fruit notes and layers of hickory smoke and maple.  The flavor is dark bitter coffee and semi-sweet chocolate with just a hint of raisins, dates and plums in the middle.  The finish has lots of wood smoke with a tiny bit of maple sweetness and a kick of spicy noble hops at the end.  Body is creamy but a little thin and aqueous with lots of soft carbonation.

Bottle. Black with a nice brown head. Licorice, coffee, a hint of cocoa, brown sugar and smoke in aroma. Malty flavours dominating at first with the hops still being present in a really nice and suitable hoppy, bitter finish. Coffee, brown sugar, licorice and smoke is the main flavours along with the dry grapy touch at the end. A very unique smoked in my opinion. Loved it.

Smokey aroma harmonizes quite well with the already big dark roasted character of BGB.  Gets a nice, lightly charred note like the beer was lightly scorched over an open fire.  Fairly dry; at the risk of sounding sexist, this is a beer for gentlemen who shave with straight razors.

500mL courtesy of TheEpeeist. Pours inkwell black with a large, reddish mocha head that is thick, rocky, lasting. Leaves 360 degree sheety lace. Massive webby lace all over the snifter. Aroma at first is coffee stout with muted burnt bacon then is tiramisu, dark chocolate, slight black olives. Taste is lemonade, tart, light-bodied, very bitter chocolate coming through. Really the opposite of what I would expect the smoked version of Beer Geek Breakfast to be. Comes across more as a schwarzbier. Tart to dry body is not on style.

Dark beer with a creamy brown head.  Really attractive nose with campfire, molasses and coffee beans.  Molasses sweetness, smoked meat, dying campfire ash, roasted grains and coffee bitterness all meld together to make a really nice smoked beer.
Bottle. Black and opague. beechwood, bacon and smoked sausage in the aroma and flavor. Hints of licorice and ash. Full bodied. fat mouthfeel, yet quite drinkable.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2014 Tap @ Palm Tavern.  The beer pours to a black body with a deep beige head.  The aroma was chocolate and smoked malts.  Some mild hops.  The flavor was fantastic!  The rauch malts really bring this beer together and balance it.  I?d love to see this beer made with the civet coffee.  The hops are pretty subdued in this beer which allows the malt to shine.  Chocolate and smoke.  Divine!  8, 5, 10, 5, 18.  Bottle on 6/30/2014... oddly bitter and harsh burnt malts.  Definitely not as I rated it before.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2010 Black with a big and lasting tan head. Aroma of coffee and licorice with touches of ink and ash. Roasted flavour with coffee and licorice, some fruit and berry and a faint hint of smoke. Full body

500ml Bottle:  Aroma of smoke, bacon, roasted malt, peat, slight vanilla, light coffee, light roasted malt, light chocolate, and some smoked meat.  Poured pitch black in color with a huge, creamy, dense, fluffy, pillowy, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.   Slightly sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is slightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, slight bacon, peat, light tar, slight meat, and smoke.  Medium to full body.  Slick, creamy texture becomes slightly dry and slightly chalky.  Soft to average carbonation.  Smoke, coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, peat, and slight tar finish is a tad dry.

Bottle: Pours an oily opaque black with a spotty-lacing froth of light brown head.  Has a lightly sweet dark chocolate and smoky nose with a hint of vinous character.  Starts with pretty good fullness and fine carbonation, but is missing the sweetness Id expect.  Has nice smoke flavor, but the coffee seems a little muted and it could use more malty sweetness for balance.  A pretty good brew, but a bit of a letdown considering how much I like coffee stouts and rauchbiers.

bouteille partagée avec Greg.
couleur nuit-noire, col moka.
arôme, léger malt fumé, aspect bien stout et qcq notes de tourbe.
goût, palais est épais, malt grillé et malt fumé qui est léger et agréable, note de tourbe moyenne. Le cote levure reste celui de Mikkeller avec nettement plus de malt grillé et fumé pour accompagner le tout.
Cest bien ce style de rauchbier qui me plaît.

Thanks to my brother for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours an inky black color with a large tan head. 

The aroma is quite a bit of smoke, but I also get a lot of chocolate and roasted malt. I also get a little bit of coffee in the aroma, but it is hidden behind the other components. 

The flavor is very similar and just as complex. The smoke is the dominant flavor, with the coffee and heavily roasted malts also being main components. I get a little bit of chocolate, but not hear as much as in the aroma. 

Medium to thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very nice big stout that incorporates smoke very well.

Pours black with a minimal tan head. Aroma is smokey, wood, roasted notes, salami and horse. Yes, horse! Taste of wood, tar, and some smokiness. Very dry mouth feel and a bit watery. Much better then I had expected actually. Thought it would have a kind of artificial smokiness that I´ve experienced on simular beers, but it´s quite balanced and genuine. Not bad at all.
