.3L serving size - $7.00 at the Brick Store Pub in Decatur, Georgia.

Appearance: Displays a heavy-looking black body on the underside of a two inch-high layer of dark tan foam.

Smell: Luscious nose suggestive of either Kahlua or Godiva liqueurs, with round notes of chocolate, chocolate, vanilla, and licorice. Sure, the smoke is registering, but, come on, wheres the smoked lardons, wheres the smoked salmon? I was told thered be lardons!

Taste: Brings to mind one of the Godiva chocolate liqueurs, with its tones of bittersweet chocolate, vanilla, and sweetened coffee. Slight drift of smoke character throughout, though still not the flood of bacon-like meatiness Id seen mentioned or had hoped for. Hints of powdered licorice root and dark fruits. Touch of underlying bitterness. More of that liqueur character for the long, chewy finish.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied. Medium carbonation. Very soft and velvety on the tongue, like the texture of melted chocolate ice cream.

Drinkability: Personally, Id hoped for more smoke as it warmed, but no dice. Still, a tasty treat to sit with down at the pub.
Black with a foamy brown head.  Actually it really does smell like bacon and smoke.  Full bodied palate.  Tastes of smoke, bacon, and molasses with a sticky finish.

Bottle split with Tony. Pours pitch brown body with nice dark, chocolately brown lacing. Aroma is delicious roasted meat - Bacon, dark chocolates, slight sweet malt. Mouthfeel is smooth with delicious notes of smoky roasted Bacon, bitter chocolate.

Split with James. This smoked oatmeal stout pours a dark black body with little head. The aroma is intense smoked bacon and oak. Really incredible aroma. The Flavor follows suit with super smokey roasted malts, minor hints of dark chocolate. Really an incredible job by Mikkeller

Bottle from West Lakeview Liquors. This is an amazing beer. Probably the best beer Ive had in a long time. Pours black with a dark tan head, which I always love to see. Nose is awesome. Campfire, chocolate, coffee, bread, pancakes, maple syrup. I swear I could smell juice in there too... On taste, Im amazed that all of the flavors are there and dont get muddied at all. Great smoke notes coupled with wonderful dark chocolate and fresh coffee. Not overly sweet either. Amazing beer.

Thanks to rateyourpoison for sharing this. Pours black with a small creamy tan head. Roast malt and smokey wood aroma Lots of cocoa and cocoa powder and coffee beans in the nose, rich and aggressive. Flavor is super rich cocoa and black coffee, very coffee bean bitter with a strong smoked woody finish. The bacon as the beer is named after really comes through in the finish to aftertaste. Finishes meaty and a camp fire note. Full rich creamy body and a soft carbonation. Delicious beer all around.

Draught at Mikkeller bar. Poured a pitch black body with a brown head. The nose was a bit of a letdown early on. Smoke, roastiness but tons of alcohol. not too bad though. The smokey roasty taste is nice, the bitterness shows up but doesnt last long into the aftertaste, balanced enough.
my date tasted and said that it reminded her of cigarettes and coffee. i agree. a thick, creamy, solid oatmeal stout all around, with a nice, smokey finish.
dark bread, smoke, black, brown foam, medium bitterness, salty, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, short finish.
Black. Has a light brown head, mostly lasting. Aroma is smoked and malty with some acid notes too. Flavor is sweet and moderate acidic, finish moderate bitter. Flavor is dry, syrupy and a bit watery.
Had as a bottle labeled as Rauch.  Poured dark brown with no head.  Light smokey toasted malty flavr with a lingering smokey finish.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of smoke, roasted malts, peat and wood.  Black hue with a nice average sized brown head that mostly diminished and left some lace.  Flavor is medium sweet and lightly bitter.  Palate is watery soft.  Overall a big disappointment.  Was hoping for a nice smokey brew but not so much.  Have no desire to try this again.

16.9 oz bottle from West Lakeview Liquors (Chicago, IL). Pours a dark blackish hue, opaque with some browner edges, thicker, huge dark dark brown head laces well, cakes big. Eventually dies to a thick film. Aromas are dense roasty malts, some sweeter dark cocoa, floral and piney hops, ashy and woody smoke, some campfire meats, caramel, toast. Initial is medium bodied, roasty barley and malts, some decent smoke, ashy and a bit smokey, roasted malts, cocoa, a touch of caramel, piney hops and big dryness, coffee. The beer works well, building on the Mikkeller BGB base, adding a growing smoke presence of campfire meats, ash, and wood with roasty malts, dark chocolate, coffee. Good hopping provides pine and dryness. The sweetness jabs here and there, but really a quite dry, bitter, growing smoke finish really grabs me as a smoke fan. Its not quite Weasel, but its a great beer and a must for Smokeheads. Yum.

Bottle shared by jtclockwork at jimmacks invitational 10. Poured a syrupy deep dark black body with a small deep brown quickly fading head. Aroma was very nice with notes of smoke, coffe, earth, licorice, tobacco and burnt toast. Full bodied with soft carbonation and a lingering roasty aftertaste. Flavors of rasted malts, burnt toast, slight smoke, burnt wood and coffee with cream. Solid beer.

22oz bottle - 

Aroma - incredible aroma of smoke, mocha, toffee bars, bakers chocolate and Tootsie Rolls.  Smoke is quite dominant.

Appearance - beautiful black body, dense, creamy dark tan/maroonish looking head, sticky lacing...so nice.

Taste - smoke straight-up front, but an unwelcome ashy character that I really dont care for in stouts shows up and it shows up quite a bit.  Ashy, burnt malts...yeeeahhh no.  I enjoyed the smoke and the dark chocolate notes though, but really hard to get around the ash.

Palate - full bodied, thick and coating mouthfeel, long semi-sweet finish, light cloying factor

Overall - apart from the overabundant flavor of ash, this was an enjoyable beer.  Loved the smoke in the aroma and flavor, but the acridness just pointed my needle in the wrong direction.

Bottle. Poured dark brown with an average light brown frothy head that was mostly lasting with very good lacing. Moderate smoke, toasted malt, peat and bacon aroma. Medium to full body with a dry smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy toasted sweet and smoke flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. Complex standout beer.

Aroma has a great smokiness thats strong but balanced. Lets enough of the oatmeal in. Poors dark with a deep brown head.Tastes even better than it smells, roasted coffee for sure. You get the sense of that bacon in the smooth finish.Wonderfully even textures and tastes. Awesome.
50cl, new Danish brew Anno 2010, thx to Jeppe!, complex smoked Stout, not too heavy, balanced, hazy, rocky head, very good brew

Tasted 2010-09-11. Pours pitch black with brown head. Aroma of coffee and smoked meat. Taste is slightly bitter. Quite mellow. A little less coffee than the original, I think. Its very good, but I prefer the regular geek breakfast.

Pour thanks to daknole! Deep brown/black with a beige head.  Aroma is heavy smoke, chocolate, leather, and a salted meat quality (honestly not quite bacon to me).  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of molasses, soy and ash.  Overall body is full and viscous and finishes with a dry roast bitterness.

16.9 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a coating tan haze.  Nose is dark chocolate, prune and sweet smoke.  Silky medium body with a tang and an oily bite on the backside.  Taste is bitter licorice, coffee bean, dates and smoky grapefruit.  A bit much for breakfast.

A: The pour is a dark brown, nearly black color with a big tan head on it.

S: Smoke, salt, and more smoke. The bacon moniker is accurate, and thats not really a good thing.

T: I thought the nose was bacon like, but the flavor has a very salty and smokey flavor and theres a distinct meaty flavor. Its almost reminiscent of smoked almonds.

M: The body is medium and the carbonation on this beer is really weird. Almost grainy, but maybe thats just the salty flavor.

D: It seems some brewers just way overdo the smoke in these kinds of beers. While I enjoy some smoke flavor in certain beers (like a porter or stout), this was like sucking down the smoke of a campfire.

Draft  Maxs.  Black, light tan creamy head.   Smoked coffee and chocolate aromas warm to a salty caramel meat-like undertone.   Roasty earthed coffee and caramelized vanilla oats ride continuous soft waves of bacon, licorice, and burnt toffee malts throughout.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, meaty, bittersweet, finish.  I can only imagine how good this would be during a Sunday brunch

Bottle.  Pours absolutely pitch black with a very pillowy and sticky tan head, suprisingly not much lacing.  Smoke and cofffee nose, maybe a touch of maple syrup in there.  Very robust flavor starts it, ashy smoke and oats, the dark roast coffee hits as it goes down, and nice bittersweet chocolate and caramel ending. A nice bitterness lasts for a while after it goes down.  The smoke is apparent but very well balanced, not overpowering.  Extremely sticky and thick, I feel like this one is sticking to my ribs.  Outstanding.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Bottle.

A - Very dark oily black color with a pretty large, very thick, extraordinarily creamy, sticky, pillowy, cafe colored head. Pretty good retention with a nice thick, very creamy, tight layer of lace.

S - Smells wonderful with with a nice smoked/bacony aroma with plenty of roasted chocolate malt. A touch of coffee, caramel and peat aromas as well, with the coffee coming out more toward the finish. Mouthwatering.

T - Similar to the nose, but with a bit less bacony flavor. Some roasted, smokey chocolate malt. Some peaty flavors come out toward the middle. Good amount of smokey flavor with some bacon/smoked meat but a bit more of a smoked wood flavor. Decent amount of black coffee comes out toward the finish. Slightly bitter taste as well.

M - Medium body with a pretty good level of carbonation. Pretty smooth and oily feel. A touch on the thin side for what I was expecting.

D - Pretty easy to drink beer with a good amount of smokey flavors, chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee. A little too smoked wood flavor for me, and if it was just a bit more bacony it would be great.

Notes: Pretty good beer. Like I said, I just wished it was a bit more bacon/meaty smoke flavor than smoked wood. Also the smokiness hides a bit of the chocolate and coffee and oat flavors as well. Overall it is an enjoyable stout and smells wonderful, but I prefer the Weasel Brunch more. That said it is a good beer worth a try, although for the price I might not get another.

Bottle, labeled as Rauch Beer Geek for the U.S. market (damn regulators.....Beer Geek Bacon is so much better).  The look is spot on.  Black, opaque, and ominous, the body holds up a thick and creamy head of dark cafe mocha foam.  Ever so slowly, the foam recedes, leaving a fan coral pattern of hard lacing etched onto the glass as it settles to a perfectly swirled film with a neat edge.  Simply beautiful.  Likewise, the nose really sings, giving notes of dark roast Italian espresso, black chocolate of a very high cacao content, creamy oats, and a sweet, smooth smoke contingent.  It doesnt come off as salty as some rauchbiers do.  Theres a subtle touch of anise, which lends its signature, licorice-like sharpness.  It smells sweet, but is sufficiently balanced by the bitterness of the coffee roast.  Great aroma overall.  The flavors are pretty darn nice as well.  Rich, bittersweet cacao and ultra-roasty, dark espresso are the theme, just like in the regular Beer Geek Breakfast, but the smooth smoke lends a deeper, complimentary earthiness.  Theres a bit of burnt caramel sweetness in there for balance, else it would be overly roasted.  Mocha stands out the most on the lengthy finish.  Now, the palate isnt perfect.  In fact, if theres a weakness here, this is it.  Though its initially smooth and creamy, with a light but persistent carbonation and a bit of a whipped feel, it gets a little sticky and saccharine on the back end.  In fact, cloying sugars coat the lips well after the glass is finished.  Otherwise, this is a mighty fine smoked stout.  Theres alot going on, and it is quite decadent, but I easily finished a bottle by myself, and I cant say that about many big stouts these days.

Bottle from Bierkoning. Dark brown with foamy tan head. Looks very, very drinkable. Nose of malts, dark fruits, prunes even and chocolate. Texture is very creamy and enjoyable. Tastes are sweet of chocolate, but also quite tart and dry. The bacon comes through and through. Wonderful collaboration by two of my favorite brewers!

Its pitch black with a huge, dark-brown, creamy and lasting head  yummi. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, charcoal, camp fire, licorice and coffee. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of roasted malt, camp fire, charcoal, licorice, coffee and the flavour lasts a very long time, perfect to let the delicious camp fire invade the mouth in the most terrific way.

Bottle. Pours midnight black with brown sugar head that looks to crystalize on top as the bubbles rise.  Nose is faintly of coffee and chocolate, with just a touch of anise.  Nothing really smokey in the aroma.  The taste is quite different, as it is initially smoky and bittersweet, like choco-coffee, with a nice mid-palate change back to full smokiness and just a hint of bacon in the late palate and finish.  Mouthfeel is relatively light, ABV comes through a bit in the final burn, and the lingering flavors on the tongue of vanilla, smoky bacon, and coffee are a real treat.  This is a high quality brew.  Very strong, and yet smooth.  Great stuff.

500ml bottle from Bev4less. Pours an opaque black color with a medium tan head that slowly fades to a fine ring. The aroma is strong with smoked meats, fireplace ashes and leather. The flavor is overtly smoky with smoked meats, leather, biter walnuts, burnt grains and blackened toast. The palate is full and smooth with soft carbonation. The finish is long and dry with lingering smoked flavors. Overall: Many smoked beers are subtly smoked and give only the slightest hint of smoke, this is not one of those beers. This is the smokiest brew that I can recall ever tasting, lots of big bold flavors, I loved it.
Draft. Color black with big head. Aroma smoked, chocolate, bacon, coffee. Taste chocolate, caramel, bacon, smoked.

Black pour.  Nice chocolate brown head.  Aroma is smoked and chocolate with some definite bacon/ham and almost some chili peppers.  Flavor is smokey, chilis, chocolate, coffee.  Not nearly bacony as I expected.  Damn good.

Bottle pours pitch black with chocolate tan head.  Aroma is bittersweet chocolate, coffee, dark roast, and a subtle smoky note.  Medium mouthfeel.  Its oily, rich, and creamy.  Flavor is everything in the nose and more.  Its super smooth and takes the base beer to a new level.  Amazing.  Simply great stuff with a smoky finish that melds perfectly with the beer.  Wow.

Draft @ Bierkoning 25 yr tasting. Solid black pour with huge dark brown head. Aroma of peat, liquorice, some smoke, caramel and malt.
Flavour is lots of peat, lots of smoke, liquorice and spices.
Lingers on and on. Nice one, although I expected a bit more smokiness.

500ml bottle from wlv....not much to say outside from what gerritt expresses...aroma had a nice cocoa chocolate nose with a moderate degree of roast slash beefy smokiness.....nice smooth chocolate flavors/aroma with a very silky smoked campfire aspect that heightened the experiencee.  nice all around quality from nose through flavored finish. ummm yeah, pretty nice beer and a slight improvement from the normalized beer geek but thats not sayin much as thats a quality beer as it stands....

A: Pours a nice rich dark black. Average mocha head no retention or lace.

S: Lots of smoked malt, hints of smoked fish, peat, caramel, and dark fruit. Chocolate, peat, coffee, peat, yum, mmm peat.

T: I have had over peated crappy mikkeller beer this is not one of them. Peat and smoke out the ass in this one, but it melds nicely with the lesser components. Rich chocolate and coffee.

M: Medium in body, very bold smoke with enough chocolate, coffee and dark fruit to add some balance.

D: Pretty good. I really like it. Solid brews. Happy Bday to me. Thanks Bosse for sending this one across the pond.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2011 Bottle at Maproom.  I have another one to give a more thorough rate later.  Yum yum yum.  Well balanced smoked malt against the piney hops and big coffee.  Supremely drinkable, perfect carbonation, rich, smooth, wonderful.   9.4.9.5.17 . . . . . . . . . . [bottle]  wow, what a pour, dark gray mocha chocolate frothy head.  Great carbonation as well in this, crisp with a smooth milky body that isnt sticky.  This is a hell of a beer, and reminds me a bit of black tie, chocolate cookie, creamy milky, light smoke and plastic, char, loses that coffee edge, not sure what I was picking up with the first rate, although that one came at closing time a bar.  9.5.8.5.17

Tap sample at De Bierkonings 25th anniversary. Black colour, deep brown head. Aroma of cream, hard roasted malts, light smoke of burning wood, coffee, chocolate. Flavour is very rich, hard roasted malts, light creamy, coffee, chocolate, good smoke, light salty, nice very dry roasted bitter finish with some hops. Fullbodied. Very very good.

Tap at hopcat. Under rauch beer geek. Black, thin body with small beige head. Full of roasted and smoked malt, dark chocolate, coffee beans, toast, and sugar. Nicely done but a tad heavy on the smoke. Doesnt have too many other bacon characteristics

on draft @ Beachwood BBQ.  Sweet smokey aroma with bitter chocolate and hints of coffee.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  Dark chocolate and roasted malts with hints of sweet smoke and vanilla, very smooth with hints of bitter earthy hops.  Excellent, just enough smoke malt.

Bottle from Berkeley Bowl West. Pours very black with a 4 finger very dark tan head. Unfortunatley the opener took a glass chip into the beer, so I may have to forgo all the leas. Well it does smell like bacon and super smooth burnt malt. Full bodied with creamy/foamy carbonation. The flavor is like really smooth oatmeal stout, but with a strongly burnt aspect and a whole lot of bacon smoke. With time a lot of darker milk chocolate comes forth. This is one heck of a thing to drink. Brilliant. Aged in single malt casks might improve it. Or not. Finishes, smooth, bacony, somewhat chocolate and definitely bitter. Brilliant (redundancy).

16.9 ounce bottle.  Served in a DFH signature glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with an inch frothy tan head.  Head retention is good, with a lot of lacing left on the glass.  Aroma is excellent, theres plenty of smoke/peat/bacon noticable, along with some dark chocolate, coffee and roasted malt.  Taste is pretty much the same as the aroma, its very smoky and roasty!  Theres also a good lingering smoky finish.  Although I think the aroma is smokier than the taste, this is still a pretty tasty brew.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its creamy and coating with low carbonation.  This brew is smooth and very easy to drink.  Its easily the smokiest brew Ive had lately, and a pretty good overall brew in general.

Pours a rich brown color with a medium mocha head.  Aroma is bitter chocolate, dark roasts, light smoke.  Taste has light hops, bitter chocolate, nice dark roasts with smoke.  Very balanced and delicious.  Stellar shit!

Thanks to my bro for sharing this.  Pours a deep brown color with medium light tan head.  Aroma is of bittersweet chocolate, light caramel malt and rich smoke.  taste is of bittersweet chocolate, light hops. smoke and sweet malt.  Finishes smooth with a bit of a dry bitterness from the chocolate.  Im a sucker for smoked beers and this delivers.

Bottle. 16 oz. Pours a motor oil black with a thick, frothy beige bead. Aroma of smoked almonds, chocolate, roast ground coffee, and soil. Full bodied with a smoky, rich velvet palate. Finishes bitter and hot. Very good.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2011 Bottle. Pours black with a thick brown head that dissipated slowly to the edges. Aroma was roasted malts with a nice added some note that definitely had a bit of bacon on it. Flavor begins full of roasted malts with some dark chocolate but a deep smokey flavor grows to a really nice finish.

Pours pretty much black in color with a 1.5-finger tannish head.  The aroma is smoky and bacony with roast and dark chocolate.  No joke on the bacon, even though I know they didnt use bacon in the beer.  The flavor is decent if a little weird.  Bacony and meaty with loads of smoke.  Roast and dark chocolate, a little coffee.  Smooth and full on the palate with fairly low carbonation.  Didnt quite live up to the awesome "Beer Geek Bacon" name, but maybe thats why they renamed it the more boring "Rauch Geek Breakfast."

Expensive treat alert! 16.9oz bottle will put you back about 10 bucks.  I think it is worth it.  Malt monster will destroy your palate.  I like how this starts off pretty sweet--though not overly sweet--and develops into this beautiful dry coffee, smoky finish.  Quite silky and full.  Bitter finish lingers a bit in the mouth, but it is tolerable.  Over here in The States, you have to put down some good money to try beers from Mikkeller or Nogne, but it is usually worth the price.
Bottle at Map Room. POurs dark brown with a rich light brown head and a cigarette and coffee aroma. The flavor is smoky dark malt with some chocolate. Very intense and tasty.

Bottle.  Black pour, medium-small tan head.  Head retention and lacing are pretty good.  Chocolate, campfire smoked bacon, sweet caramel, and hint of vanilla.  Creamy mouthfeel.  This is a nice smoked stout.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a brown head. Nice. Tart, dry, roasted aroma with some subdued smoked notes; think it could do with more outspoken ones. Roasted, smoked flavour. A bit of alcoholic burn. Bitter hops in the background. Full-bodied. Dry, but tart, roasted finish with more alcoholic burn. Slight grassy notes. As it warms, notes of dark fruits appear as well as some lingering coffee notes. Overall nice, but lacks some oomph. 06.08.10.

Black; light/medium tan head. Very rich, pungent aroma - roast, coffee, oil, licorice, wood. Similar to Deschutes The Abyss in some ways, viz. lots of licorice. This is quite a bit better however. Flavor - rubber, salty, iodine, licorice. Camp fire smoke. Is it just me or does Mikkeller make some bad ass stouts

Bottle thanks Dalzale. Pour is deep brown black with tight soapy head which leaves a ring on top. Aroma is pure meat locker and beef jerky. Taste more the same with faint hints of coffee and coco. Palate is slick and dry finish. Tasty and hearty!

Bottle.  Dark black pour, a little carbonation and a very meaty and beef jerky-like aroma,  Flavor is plenty of smoked malt, peat, salted meat and finished with a long lingering campfire aftertaste.  Solid and enjoyable.

Rating #416, bottle from Ølbutikken  

A black beer that leaves lacings on the glass. Aroma is smoke, coffee, hops and chocolate. Likewise is the flavours smoke, coffee, chocolate, light hops and sweet roasted malts. This version of beer geek manages to create a very fine balance between its elements. The smoke is powerful enough to be a main-element in the beer, but still it is subdued enough to not take over and outrule the other elements. The sweetness brings in a very pleasent touch to a stout I remember as being very hopped and a bit dry. The hops are distinct enough to make a solid impression in the finish, but still subdued enough to give space to the smoke. Palate is easily creamy, soft, and body is thick. A nice expierience.

Pours opaque black with brown-tan head that is fizzy first, then turns into cream.  Good head retention and lacing.  Aroma is powerful coffee and roast malts, with a whiff of smokiness.  Flavor is robust, again reflecting deeply roasted coffee.  Smoke flavor on the tail-end - slightly artificial tasting.  Dry bitter finish that lasts.  Very smooth and slick.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2011 Tap at Rattle n Hum. Pours black with a thick, creamy brown head. Intense roasted malt aroma with char, tobacco and dark chocolate. Lightly sweet with a pervasive roasty character. There are mild notes of smoke and cured meat, though certainly not as pronounced as some other smoke beers Ive had. I take this mildness as a good thing, though, as some smoke beers I find too "out there," living in novelty beer land. This Mikkeller is quite drinkable. The body is medium and the carbonation light and smooth. Finishes with lingering dry roast notes and light saltiness. A good beer for sure. Update: had some more of this at the Euston Tap last night, thanks to Thomas who shared his bottle. Again, I rated a 4. Great beer.

Tap at RnH: Opaque pour with a deep brown head. Rich meaty black malt aroma- quite charred with a burnt plum note, fennel and black licorice. Light fluffy carbonation- feels like a nitro pour, although it wasnt. Huge charred flavor. Little sweetness with a ton of ashy smoke. Lots of burnt black malt with a slight astringency. One dimensional without a complex smoke profile like that of Alaskan Smoked Porter.

500mL - Rauch Geek Breakfast - bottle. Pour is jet black with a smallish tan head that falls away rather quickly leaving a thick ring of lace around the rim of the glass. Aroma is smoky, malty, dark roasted coffee and chocolate with a touch of caramel. Flavor up front is vanilla, caramel, chocolate followed by smoked bacon, peated malt and dark coffee in the finish. Over all an incredible, complex stout, creamy, smoky, what a treat and for my $$ right on the money.
Ppours black with a thin tan head to it. Basically smells like bacon. Thats all I can think of when I smell this. Has a smokey, wood, and slight chocolate taste to it. Pretty damn tasty overall.

500mL "Rauch Geek Breakfast" bottle.  Pours an opaque black with a thick and creamy chestnut head that leaves rings of lacing behind.  Smoke, BBQ, some bacon, toasted pumpernickel, semi-sweet chocolate, and a bit of caramel in the appealing aroma.  Goes down thick and creamy with a little bite.  Some lightly sweet caramel is present upfront taste-wise and is quickly followed by touches of vanilla and dark chocolate along with some burnt pumpernickel.  Very earthy and grainy.  A bitterly dry roasted coffee finish.  Plenty of smoke and saltiness apparent all the way through.

skibsøl comes to mind when you drink this smoke-infused brew, but where skibsøl is only 2-point-something abv, this brew is a tad stronger. still manages to clear your throat with a nose of heavily smoked bacon, a little plastic, a broad feel with well-balanced carb, the taste is chocolate and smoke. somewhere theres some fruit just as the beer hits the tongue. cant define which though

Opaque black with a small, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of smoked meat, roasted malts, burnt wood, chocolate, adn alcohol.  Taste of roast, burnt wood, smokey malts, dark chocolate, and a strong, dry, smokey finish.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black beer with a lightbrown head. The aroma is malt, caramel, smoke, peat, coffee and licorice. The flavor is malt, peat, coffee and licorice. The palate is smoke and malty. Overall a beer with a good balance and a good level of smoke.

Poured black from a "Rauch Geek Breakfast" bottle with a brown head that fades quickly.  Aroma is mainly chocolate malts but with a good amount of smoky bacon notes.  Taste also has lots of smoked wood flavors with chocolate.  Some sweet vanilla flavors as well.  Doesnt really taste like bacon, which is probably a good thing.  Finish has some coffee and chocolate malts.  Overall very smooth and well balanced, but I definitely prefer the beer geek breakfast.

Appearance:  Pours a midnight brown with a creamy, frothy tan head.

Aroma:  Concentrated smoked malt, heavily roasted coffee, dark chocolate.

Taste:  Smoked ham rind, coffee roast, burnt roast, dark chocolate, cracked black pepper, spicy hops.

Mouthfeel:  Slightly creamy, prickles the back of the throat.

Overall: Amazing, complex, not real bacony, but amazing none the less.

wow. Fat and smokey, meaty. Black, portly. Bacon? Maybe. Lotsa smoke, charcoal, roast, wood,meat. Small brown head, nice lace. Bandaids, chocolate and grain. Fekkin awsome smoked! Not something youd drink alot of in one sitting but for the ocassional palate cleanser,,, hells yeah!!

Bottle 500ml. @ The Danish Summer Gathering, TTODRBSG10 - Ulfborg.Clear dark black color with a large, frothy to creamy, excellent lacing, fully lasting, light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, burnt, coffee, light to moderate hoppy, smoke - bacon meat. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long to average duration, peaty smoke and meat smoke. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100814]

Taster at DØK.
Bottled, 140810.
Black with beige head. Aroma of coffee and a tone of smoke. Flavor with roasted malt and spices.

On tap at the brickstore. Pours a decent black with a quarter inch brown head. The smoke here is very understated and quite complementary as opposed to overpowering and taking over the rest of the drink. That allows some of the roasty malt and coffee flavors to sneak through on the front of the palate. Well balanced conglomeration of flavors here.

Bottle at home. Pours an opaque black with a light brown head. Sweet with some bitterness. Aromas of roasted and smoked malts with dark chocolate. Quite hoppy. The high bitterness combined with the smoked aromas gives hints of ash aroms. Also hints of vanilla. Full bodied. Medium to high carbonation. Long bitter, smoked roasted finish. Lovely.
On tap at Håndverkerstuene. Pitch black colour with a medium big head. Aroma is malty, coffee, toffee and smoke. Flavour is also coffee, toffee, liqorice and some smoke. It has a short aftertaste.

330 ml draught at Håndverkerstuene. Pitch black with a creamy light beige head that clings to the glass. Mellow smokey aroma with roasted malts and quite a bit of body. Theres a lot of protein in this beer for sure. Feels thick and rounded. Smooth. Very flavourful and rich. A delicious beer.

Bottle picked up and shared at SL. Thanks robert. Great pour, monster head, black in color. Good smoke aroma with some malt backbone. Taste is a dry but smokey beer, not picking up any smoked meats... Just a nice smokiness.... Light coffee, malty with a roasted malt. Creamy smooth, easy to drink. I prefer the regular beek geek breakfast, but this is nice. Thanks robert.

Pours pitch black with an enormous tan head that recedes very, very slowly to a one-finger cap and leaves impressive lacing.  Gorgeous beer.

Whoa!  Hello smoked meat.  Summer sausage, bacon, burnt hickory, spicy wood.  Its all about the smoke with only a little bit of dark malts and coffee in the background.  Loved this aroma.

The taste isnt quite as intense but its seriously smoky with hickory smoked sausage and bacon.  There is roasted black malts and coffee.  Spicy sausage aftertaste.

The mouthfeel is creamy and close to full bodied though the finish is lighter and dry.

This is a fantastic beer.  Im a big fan of smoked beers, so this one really hit the spot.  Mikkel really knows how to make a stout as Ive rarely had a bad one.  That said, with this beer, you better like smoked meat!

Draft. Poured as Mikkeller Rauch Geek Breakfast. Smoky smell dominates the nose. Dark black pour with a slight tan head. Coffee notes as well. Sweet upfornt with smoke taste that builds as you sip and the beer warms. Medium mouthfeel. Slight bitter ending. Not a huge smoke fan but this one is ok in my book. Glad I tried it but nothing I would seek out.

pitch black, smooth light brown head.
roasted and pepperty aroma. very dry, some hops. nice
flavor is roasted stuff, licorice, dark roasted malts, coffee,

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2010 Black with a medium beige head. Sweet nose with burned malt, english liqeurice, smoke and coffee. Sweet flavor with hard roasted malt, ham, coffee, smoke and hints choffee. Finished smoked.

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of Pinball. Pitch black with a small and dissipating light brown head. Smoky nose - I think I pick up both Bamberg smoke and peat. Solid body, sweet hard roast, a little tar - the smoke is less prominenct now. Dry, hard roast malt bitterness. 140810

Bottle, 7.5%. Black colour. Very small dark brown head. The flavour is roasted with a good coffee note and a nice creamy touch. Has a little smoke, not enough to dominate, but does well to add an interesting touch.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2010 Rauch geek breakfast bottle. Pours black with very frothy tan head. Nose is roasted malts, smoked wood, hops and smoke. Taste is light smoke, light BBQ and roasted malts. I was definitely hoping for more of a smoke character with this brew, but its tasty.
Bottle. Collision of a good smoked and beer geek breakfast, so woody peat, smoke aroma and flavors added to bgb. A little bit of coffee lost due to the smoke, intensity wise.

Draft, sold as Rauch Geek Breakfast.  Very dark maroon, dark brown edge head that settles quickly.  Aroma of ash tray and bitter cocoa.  Taste is over-roasted coffee beans, prominent smoke, bitter burnt espresso.  Complex and tasty.  No bacon, though, sorry.

Bottle. Pours with a thick black body and a deep, iodine head. Coats the glass.  Head stays. Aroma of chocolate, oatmeal, truffles, dust, earth, smoke, dusty, cracklins. Dusty rich coffee. Taste is bitter, earthy, dusty, smoke, really astringently bitter. A bit of vanilla and wood. Super bitter, oppressively so. Mocha. Medium to high bubbles. Medium-dry lasting finish.

16.9 oz bottle, label says "Rauch Geek Breakfast" but has an identical label.  Basically black pour with tan ring around the glass.  Aroma of smoke and chocolate.  Some coffee, some roast.  A bit of a light sour twang from the oats.  Smoke and chocolate dominate the flavor, with some coffee and roast to balance the beer out.  Theres also a lot of meat and a omnipresent saltiness. The beer is incredibly dry,  and the roast becomes more apparent as it warms.  Really digging the roast/chocolate/smoke/salt/coffee thing going on here.  Pretty nice beer.

Bottle from  Ølkonsortiet, Aalborg.  Dark chocolate-brown cream head. Body is black, with a dark mahogny edge when holding it up to the light.  Coffee, chocolate and hard roasted malts on the nose. Smoke too, of coarse. But not nearly as dominating as expected. Rounded and well integrated. Big malt body. Seriously roasted, with bitter chocolate and coffee ground. Both sour and salty, with a light sweetness underneath. More smokey and peaty than the aroma indicate. Supersmooth in the mouth. Thick and filling. Overall, a very well-crafted Stout. Impressivly balanced!

Tap at Håndverkerstuene. Coal black with a fat, creamy brown head on top which stays all the way and leaves chunky, sticky lacing along the glass. Aroma is very burnt and smoky, some bitter and sweet chocolate, coffee, ashes, tar and some alcohol. Very sweet at first when sipped, which yields to a raw, bitter and burnt coffee and smoky middle. Som chocolate as well. Dry, burnt finish. Alcohol completely hidden. This is one fat, creamy and viscous brew, very nice mouthfeel. This is uncompromising, raw and harsh. For some reason I feel its harsher than some Islay barrel aged beers Ive had, although that does seem unlikely. Maybe it was just me that night. A little bit too bitter perhaps. Not as salty and tar like as islay aged ones. Still, good stuff.

Loads of smoke, liquorice, soo, even, yes, fat bacon. Long full smokiness.
Velvet coffee underneath, a little alcohol warming. One of their very best.
Smoked ,chocolate,oatmeal,coffee flavors,Soy sauce kind aroma,high c02,thick body.I liked it a lot

Big dark brown head. Utterly opaque black body. Burnt smoky meaty aroma with chocolatey resin and pine needle notes. Dry brnt mealy pine needle taste with roasty campfire notes. Mid-bodied. Mild mealy mouthfeel. Dry mealy burnt pine needle aftertaste with resiny chocolatey soot notes. Lovely, uncompromising, and harsh beer. (0.5l bottle, Fish and Beer, Copenhagen.)

Tap at Mikkeler bar after watching Inception.
Nice very dark brown look with a medium brown creamy head. Aroma is mainly roasted malts and coffee with peat, soy and fruits. Great complex flavor of roasted coffee, sweet raisins, smoke and salt. Good stuff

Bottle. Black pour, small yet frothy brown head. Aroma is big on roast and smoke, with a little peat, giving a hint of meat, and some rope. Otherwise lots of coffee and bitter chocolate as well. Soft and buttery aroma. Taste is bigger on the smoke and tar, but just manages to remain refined and subtle. Also some peat and whiskyish characteristics, chocolate and some hops in the finish. Low carbonation, long duration, big body. Lovely!

Pours an opaque black color with a brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, smoke, roast, toast, some toffee, and slightly earthy. Flavor is caramel, toast, roast, chocolate, coffee, smoke, and a bitter roast slightly hoppy finish.

Black of color with a very nice brown head. An aroma of liqurice, hops, raosted malt, dusty, tar, coffee and smoke. A flavor of smoke, liqurice, roasted malt, hops, oldfashioned liqurice, soy sauce and a dry finish. mmm...
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, cold coffee, liquorish and light peated smoke. Flavour is roasted malt, cold coffee, liqourish and peated smoke.
50 cl bottle. Black with small brown head. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, oat and smoke.

Bottle, bought @ LIVA, Kolding.
Pours all black with a fine, large, creamy, dark cappucino head. Fair duration, fine lacings. Aroma has lots of coffee, dark chocolate and a fine, smoky undertone. There is a lot of it, really, but its well balanced out with the regular BGB malty sweetness. Some fruity hops creep in as well. Light vinious. Medium carbonation, fine fresh and dryish creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has fine balanced smokiness, lots of dry coffee, dark chocolate, light vinious. Fair dryness with good chocolate, mild fruity hops. Long, lingering malty bitter finish.  Very good, though Id still prefer the regular.

Draught at Ørsted 2010-07-27
Black, light brown fast disappearing head. Aroma of salt, tar, smoke and liqourice. Taste is salty and reminds of newly cut wood and Seville orange. Almost no carbonation.

Draught. Pitch black colour, small brown head. Very roasty bit smokey aroma with chocolate and coffee. Good mouthfeel. Roasted malt with smoke in the flavour along with chocolate, coffee, ok bitterness. Roasty chocolate smokey finish with some alcohol,

Bottle @ J.C.G US Tasting, Pt 3. Pours black with a creamy brown head and lacings. Nose is coffee, liquorice, smoke, oat and vague smoke. Flavor is dry and roasted with notes of oat, coffee and vague smoke. Very smooth and full palate. Nice one

24-JUL-2010, bottle @home, from "Fish & Beer".
Looks like a cake:) Huge, huge brown head on almost black body.
Roasted nose with coffee but also smoke. Not overly smoked, but just a fair amount - enough to add some complexity without making it a "Rauchbier".
Loong slightly hoppy aftertaste following a very creamy mouthfeel.
This is a fine brew.
Bottle.Pitch black colour with off-beige head.Aroma of earth and tar smoked and with flavor of smoked ham and burnt wood full body and creamy finish.

500 ml unlabelled bottle, a gift from Mikkeller/Nøgne Ø via Cardinal. Black colour, big brown head. Strong roasty and smoky aroma, notes of tar and old rope rather than bacon (well yes, some uncooked bacon too). The flavour is roasty with notes of strong coffee, dark bitter chocolate and tar, also distinct smoky notes, but not quite as extreme as I expected. Hints of liquorice too, not very sweet. Ah, beer - so much more than a breakfast drink!

Bottle. Deep black pour with a good looking but fast disappearing dark brown head. Stunning looks. Aroma has a lot of rich espresso coffee, delicious chocolate. The smoke takes on a subtle role behind those two main scents and behind the smoke is dark caramel, berry notes and bacon along with sirupy chocolate. The taste has a lot of nice coffee on top. Behind that there is smoke, bitter chocolate, refreshing hops, chocolaty and caramely sweetness, a rather high bitterness consisting of bitter espresso notes along with hops. Notes of strong cocoa nibs and sweet tobacco. Vague salty and espresso bitter finish. Lacks a bit of sweetness in when below 12 degress celsius, but the aroma and the looks compensate for that. Rather light mouthfeel, medium body. I expected a punch in the smokey balls, but the smoke was very subtle and only a bit more tracable than in the regular BGB. The two are very alike.

Bottle 50cl. Pours a pitch black with a impressive massive brown head - more brown than most I have ever seen - It have almost a grey glow. The nose are first of all smokey like long hung spanish ham. Then it is topped with caramel, chocolate and malty notes then blends perfectly with wooden (?), coffee and alcohol notes. The taste is surprisingly mild with a medium mouthfeel. A strong malty and hoppy bitterness with lots of smoke and touches of alcohol. I is definetly an "adults-only" beer with plenty of testoteron. Really a good masculin beer.

Bottled. Pitch black coloured. Dense brown head. Aroma is roasted, chocolaty, has some smoke and ligth bacon notes. Flavour is smoky, sweet, vague fruity, roasted and chocolaty. Medium to full bodied. Ends on a chocolaty roasted bitterness ´with a light touch of smoke. Very balanced and smooth.
On tap at Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Pitch black colour, light brown head. Nose of smoked meat and roasted malt. Full-bodied. Rich flavour of dry liquorice, coffee, malt.

From tap at the Mikkeller bar. Pours dark brown to black with a creamy, dense and chocolate brown head. Aroma is classic beer geek with mild smoked whiff. Light marmelade fruity hops note. Smoked, ashtray and slight tarish. Slight salty. Vague chocolate malty note. Vague chalky and ashtray like into a dry and mild smoked finish. Lasting dry dark malty, chocolate and light smoked into the far finish.

Fad: Kulsort øl med et flot lysebrunt skumhoved. Duft af røg og brændte malte. Ikke så kraftig som jeg havde regnet med, men stadig lækker. Smagen er yderst velafbalanceret imellem røgen og den sædvanlige Beer Geek, dog er den en tand mere rund og mild end den normale. Dette er et stort plus i min bog. Dejlig øl.

Draft. A pitch black beer with a lazing dark brown head. The aroma has notes of dextrose?, smoke, roasted malt, and coffee - where does the dextrose note come from? The flavor is sweet with notes roasted malt, coffee, soy sauce, smoke, and bacon, leading to a dry, roasted, smoked, and coffee finish. The body is thick.

Bottle. Pours deep dark brown with a nice lacing cappuccinno colored head. Aromas of licorice, smoke, chocolate and coffee. Sweet and roasted flavor with notes of smoke, tobacco and coffee. Tasty and easy drinkable brew.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar.
Pitch black coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Roasted aroma of smoke, coffee and dark chocolate.
Roasted flavour of coffee with notes of dark chocolate, hops and smoke.
Roasted and smoked finish.

On tap at Mikkeller Bar. Its pitch black with a dense tan head. The aroma is roast, smoke, light chocolate and liquorice. Lovely flavour of liquorice, tobacco, smoke, coffee, hard roasted malt and light chocolate. its full bodied and full flavoured. Great brew!
Drauht at MikkellerBAR. Pitch black - brown head. Nice smokey aroma. Chocolate. Coffee. Nice malty. Light milkey. Nice high coffee. Smooth body. Light sweetness.

Bottle. It pours a pitch black body and a two-finger, creamy tan head that lasts. Its quite burnt on the nose, with a pleasant but a bit weak smoke aroma. Coffee, dark chocolate and licorice also blends in. Its full-bodied and smooth on the palate, dry yet with a malty sweetness. The flavor has the usual suspects, coffee, chocolate and some licorice, but its the burnt, lightly smoked flavors that makes it stand out in the crowd. In the very end theres a fine hoppy bitterness too, adding some extra to the experience. A really pleasant beer, and it goes well with breakfast. 100702

Pours jet black with a nice tan head.Aroma of smoke,tar,chocolate and lots of roast.Flavour is chocolate and smoke with some roast and a little soy sauce.Mouthfeel is full and the carobonation is mwdium. Overall a very nice beer

On tap @ Patricks. Pitch black body with a fine, lasting brown head. Strong aroma of malt, coffee, dark chocolate and smoke. Flavor is sweet, medium roasted malt, chocolate, dry fruit, liquorices and warming alcohol. Complex, smooth flavor with a long and quite bitter aftertaste together with roasted malt and warming alcohol. The roast and smoke flavor is very delicate integrated with the rest of the flavors, not to dominating but definitively present. Delicious, really tasty and still surprisingly easy to drink.
chocolate, smoke, coffee, black, hazy, tan foam, heavy cloying sweetness, very bitter, salty, medium sourness, full body, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish,
